DOC.HEAD: Juries Tougher Than Judges On Convicted Felons, Report Says
DOC.TEXT: The term ``hanging judge'' may have to be rethought. More people convicted of felonies by state court juries wind up in prison than those found guilty by judges, and they spend a longer time incarcerated, says a study released Sunday. At the same time, the overwhelming majority of convicted felons _ 89 percent _ plead guilty, and those who own up to their misdeeds spend a shorter time in prison than those convicted by a judge or a jury, the Justice Department reported. The penalties of life in prison or death are meted out to 47 percent of those convicted by juries of murder or non-negligent manslaughter. Meanwhile, only 15 percent of those who pleaded guilty to such charges and 12 percent of those found guilty by a judge received those penalties, said the report by the department's Bureau of Justice Statistics. It is unclear why defendants convicted by juries were more severely punished, the study said. But it noted that ``a higher percentage of the convictions by juries were for violent offenses.'' Within each type of offense _ ranging from murder to drug trafficking to larceny _ ``a higher percentage of particularly serious cases may have been decided by juries,'' the study said. ``Defendants in such serious cases, violent and nonviolent, may have been less willing to plead guilty because they expected very severe penalties,'' it added. ``In addition, prosecutors may have recommended and judges may have imposed shorter sentences for those who pled compared to those found guilty by trial.'' The study _ based on information from 100 counties in 37 states regarding all convicted felons sentenced in 1986 _ cautioned that the findings should be considered preliminary because of the limited sample size. The next survey is to cover 300 jurisdictions. Of the estimated 583,000 people convicted of a felony in state courts in 1986, 89 percent pleaded guilty, 8 percent were convicted by a jury and 3 percent were found guilty by a judge, the report says. But many of the guilty pleas were for lesser offenses, with 92 percent of the larceny convictions and 90 percent of the burglary convictions based on guilty pleas, but only 58 percent of the murder convictions and 68 percent of the rape convictions based on such pleas. Felons convicted by a jury were sentenced to an average of 159 months in prison, compared with 103 months when felons were convicted by a judge and 72 months for those who pleaded guilty. Also, 84 percent of felons convicted by a jury were sentenced to prison or jail rather than probation or other types of sentences, while 71 percent of those convicted by a judge were incarcerated and only 65 percent of those who pleaded guilty were incarcerated. Prison sentences, not including jail terms, were handed down to 71 percent of those convicted by a jury, 50 percent of those found guilty by a judge and 44 percent of those who pleaded guilty.

DOC.HEAD: Students Battle in Bangladesh; At Least 2 Killed
DOC.TEXT: Rival student political groups fired pistols and sawed-off shotguns and hurled homemade bombs at each other Sunday, killing at least two people and wounding 12 others, police and witnesses said. Vice Chancellor Abdul Mannan said Dhaka University would be closed indefinitely, and students in the 13 dormitories were ordered to leave the campus by Sunday night. The fighting broke out when supporters of two opposition parties, the Awami League and the Bangladesh Nationalist Party, tried to conduct rallies at the same place at the same time. The parties called the rallies to protest attacks on each other's supporters last Wednesday. Demonstrators fired at least 100 rounds of ammunition and threw several small bombs during the 40-minute clash, according to police who spoke on condition of anonymity. Police fired rifles in the air and tear gas to break up the fighting. They said police gunfire did not cause any casualties. Shahidul Islam, a central leader of the Bangladesh Students League which is affiliated with the Awami League, was shot in the forehead and died instantly, police said. The identity of another slain student was not immediately known. Hours after the clash, Awami League supporters vented their anger by hurling stones and damaged about 12 vehicles parked in front of their office in central Dhaka, said police officials speaking on condition of anonymity. Campus rallies frequently turn violent in Bangladesh. Wednesday's trouble started during commemorations marking the anniversary of the deaths in 1952 of at least five students known as ``the language martyrs.'' The 1952 killings by police occurred during a demonstration to make Bangla an official language in East Pakistan. East Pakistan became the independent nation of Bangladesh in 1971 after a nine-month war between the Bangla-speaking East Pakistanis and the West Pakistanis who dominated the national government and used Urdu as the state language. The Awami League and the Bangladesh Nationalist Party both oppose the present Bangladeshi government of President Hussain Muhammad Ershad, but supporters of the two parties often clash. University officials said at least 10 Dhaka University students have died in clashes between the two opposition parties in the past four years.

DOC.HEAD: Police Prevent Pro-Democracy Protest Marches in Nepal
DOC.TEXT: Riot police armed with rifles arrested at least 150 people Sunday to prevent marches by pro-democracy demonstrators demanding the government lift its 29-year-old ban on political parties. The protesters, shouting ``Long live the revolution!'' were taken into custody as they entered Katmandu's main shopping district of New Road to begin marching, said witnesses who spoke on condition of anonymity. The planned march was one of several scheduled around Nepal by two banned political groups, the Nepali Congress Party and a left-wing coalition, who are leading a movement for more political freedom. Political demonstrations are not allowed in Nepal. According to the government, at least 12 people have been killed since Feb. 18 when the movement was launched to demand restoration of a multiparty democracy. Activists say the death toll is nearly double the government figure. Activists said at least 1,000 people were taken into custody Sunday, mostly in the capital, but the witnesses, who have proved reliable in the past, said they only saw about 150 people being herded into a police station. The police refused to give any figures. Residents contacted by telephone said police also arrested demonstrators in the southeastern town of Dharan on Sunday, but they had no details. The outcome of the other planned marches was not immediately known. The state-run news agency said without elaborating that ``some persons who tried to raise undesirable slogans'' were arrested in the southern town of Nepalganj. The report was the only reference by the government to any demonstration in the Himalayan kingdom, one of the world's oldest monarchies. Witnesses said those arrested in Katmandu included Hari Bol Bhattarai, former mayor of the city and a senior member of the Nepali Congress, and Padma Ratna Tuladhar, a left-wing member of the National Assembly. Both were waving the black flags adopted by the new pro-democracy movement and were shouting anti-government slogans when policemen tore the flags from their hands and took them away, said witnesses. Earlier Sunday, more than 100 doctors and nurses in the country's largest hospital walked off their jobs for more than one hour in support of the pro-democracy movement. They gathered outside the 300-bed Bir Hospital in the capital, wearing black armbands over their white jackets. ``We mourn the death of our people,'' said one doctor, who refused to give his name for fear of reprisals. ``This is a protest against the government's violation of human rights.'' Medical students said in a statement they supported the movement. In Katmandu, hundreds of steel-helmeted policemen, wearing chest pads and carrying rifles, batons, bamboo shields and tear-gas canisters, patrolled the 2-square-mile New Road area, watched by reporters and throngs of tourists. Shops were closed, and only police vans and a few private vehicles were allowed in the usually bustling area. The government has accused the demonstrators of trying to impose their brand of democracy on a country which it says already has a working democracy. Power in Nepal is shared between the king and the National Assembly. One-fifth of the assembly's 140 members are nominated by the king. The rest are elected on a non-party basis. Advocates of multiparty democracy say the elections are a farce and that the only candidates allowed are those approved by King Birendra or his associates. Nepal's two-year experiment with Western-style democracy ended in 1961 when then-King Mahendra, the present monarch's father, dissolved the government of the Nepali Congress Party, accusing it of corruption and poor administration.

DOC.HEAD: Justice Considering Hiring Private Company for Nazi-Hunting Work
DOC.TEXT: The Justice Department is weighing whether to farm out to private business the work of government historians who furnish research ammunition for the agency's special Nazi-hunting unit. The proposal is being studied as part of the Bush administration's effort to save money by ``privatizing'' certain functions performed by government workers. But it has caused alarm in some circles that the work of the unit _ the Office of Special Investigations _ will be undermined. An official of the Simon Wiesenthal Center, the leading research center on the mass extermination of Jews before and during World War II, criticized the idea, saying it comes at a time when changes in Eastern Europe will give unprecedented access to Nazi records. ``It is absolutely beyond belief that a diminution of the work of OSI would be considered at this point,'' said Rabbi Abraham Cooper, associate dean of Los Angeles-based center. He said changes in East Germany make it likely that the Justice Department will be able for the first time to study the files of the Gestapo in East Berlin _ and that this opportunity must be seized. ``Contracting work to the outside, I'm afraid, might be the signal that the government is looking to begin the process of paring back the work of the OSI,'' Cooper said. Justice Department spokesman Doug Tillett denied that, saying ``we obviously want to make sure there is no diminution in the level of services provided by the OSI employees.'' Tillett said the department is only studying the feasibility of hiring a private contractor to do the work. The study was undertaken to comply with a White House Office of Management and Budget directive that all agencies identify jobs that could be contracted out to private companies, he said. Government historians are listed by OMB as positions that could be turned over to private contractors, he said. Tillett said contractors must show they can do the work for a price that is 10 percent lower than what it now costs the government. The plan envisions using a private company to do the work of six government historians. These government employees over the years have read German, Russian and other East European languages, authenticated and interpreted World War II-era documents that prosecutors used to prove involvement in Nazi persecution of Jews and other war crimes. They are described by former Justice Department officials as key participants in the investigations conducted by the OSI. Since it was founded in 1979, that unit has investigated more than 1300 cases of suspected Nazis living in this country. During the last 11 years, 27 former Nazis have been deported or extradited to other countries after the Justice Department unearthed proof they were involved in Nazi war crimes. The typical Nazi war criminal identified by Justice Department investigators was a former guard at a concentration camp or the member of an SS militia that persecuted Jews or other ethnic groups in Nazi-occupied countries. They came to this country by concealing their Nazi past to U.S. immigration authorities. Martin Mendelsohn, a Washington attorney who helped set up the unit when he worked at the Justice Department, also criticized the plan. ``Given the fact that office has been understaffed for years, they shouldn't be further reducing the number of people that they have,'' said Mendelsohn. The department would be losing many experienced people, he said. ``Most of them have been there for some time.'' Jeffrey N. Mausner, a former Justice Department lawyer who worked in the unit, said the six employees ``serve both as historians and investigators.'' ``They locate documents, determine the historical significance of the documents,'' Mausner said. They also help locate witnesses to bolster the Justice Department's evidence, he said. Besides German and Russian, the historians are expert in Baltic and Balkan languages, he said.

DOC.TEXT: Garrison Keillor has returned to his roots, broadcasting his ``American Radio Company of the Air'' from the World Theater, from which his ``Prairie Home Companion'' originated. ``It's so lovely to come back to this old theater,'' Keillor, who left Minnesota in 1987 and lives in New York, said in Saturday's broadcast. ``It's like no time has elapsed. It's like we're back where we were, wherever that was.'' His monologue dealt with life as a Minnesotan in New York City. He talked about the ``exclusive'' Loon Club where he and other Minnesota expatriates gather to eat macaroni and cheese, tell Knute and Ole jokes and imitate the call of the loon. Guest Bob Elliott of the comedy team of Bob and Ray encouraged aged vacationers to skip Disney World and take the guided canoe tour of the Archdiocese of St. Paul and Minneapolis. The Minnesota Public Radio show went out to about 250 public radio stations nationwide.

Ben Vereen cited his own past involvement with drugs in telling about 600 students at an inner-city school not to waste time and talent by using drugs. ``You have genius inside of you. Don't believe everything on television telling you that you can't do anything. You can,'' said Vereen, founder of Celebrities for a Drug-Free America. The 43-year-old actor-dancer, appearing through Sunday with the Milwaukee Symphony Orchestra, said he spent almost 20 years under the influence of drugs. ``I regret that. Most of all I regret the wasted time,'' he said Friday at Fulton Middle School. ``I never had enough time with my daughter.'' He said he gave up drugs shortly after the death of his daughter, Naja, at the age of 16 in a 1987 traffic accident.

Former Black Panther Stokely Carmichael, now using the name Kwame Ture, is updating his 1960s call to political action, recruiting students for his All African People's Revolutionary Party. ``If you don't join our party, then join some other party. ... If you can't find an organization you like, then make your own party,'' he said in a speech at Laney College. ``You must help your people,'' Ture, 48, said Friday. ``If you don't, by your very inactivity, you are against your people.'' As Stokely Carmichael, he headed the Student Non-Violent Coordinating Committee during the civil rights struggles of the '60s. He later joined the Black Panther Party. In 1979 he named himself after African revolutionary leaders Kwame Nkrumah and Sekou Ture. He now lives in the West African nation of Guinea and promotes African unification under a socialist system.

Jaime Escalante, the inner-city teacher whose devotion to his profession inspired the movie ``Stand and Deliver,'' has been honored by the American Association of School Administrators. Escalante, a math teacher at Garfield High School, received the 1990 American Education Award on Saturday. Past honorees include Sally Ride, Walter Cronkite and Walt Disney. Escalante was cited for his devotion to ``instilling confidence in his underprivileged Hispanic students and pushing them to greater heights of success.''

Robert Mays, who waged a bitter battle over the apparent hospital swap of his daughter and another baby has married for the third time in a ceremony that included the girl he's raised as his own for 11 years. Mays, 44, and Darlena Souza, 32, were wed Saturday in Orlando. Kimberly Mays, who learned in November that Mays is not her biological father, was a large part of the ceremony. ``We're going to accept one another in our vows and then we'll accept (Kim),'' Mays said earlier. ``She's going to play a big part of it.'' Genetic tests showed that Kimberly is the daughter of Ernest and Regina Twigg, formerly of Langhorne, Pa., and that the girl the Twiggs raised and named Arlena was really the daughter of Mays and his first wife, Barbara. Arlena died of heart disease in 1988. In an agreement last year with the Twiggs, Mays was allowed to keep Kimberly. Barbara Hays died of cancer in 1981, shortly after the girl's second birthday. Another marriage lasted more than six years, ending in divorce.

DOC.HEAD: Candidates in 1990 Senate Races Already Have Raised $62 Million
DOC.TEXT: Candidates in 1990 Senate races raised $62 million last year, topped by Republican Sen. Phil Gramm of Texas who received nearly $6 million in contributions, federal statistics show. Gramm was among four incumbents raising more than $3 million, according to the analysis released Sunday by the Federal Election Commission. The others were Sens. Bill Bradley, D-N.J., with $4.7 million; Rudy Boschwitz, R-Minn., with $3.6 million; and Paul Simon, D-Ill., with $3.3 million. Twenty-two people reported contributions of more than $1 million, all of them incumbents except three Republican House members and Texas Democrat Hugh Parmer, a state senator taking on Gramm. Rep. Lynn Martin, R-Ill., reported raising $1.5 million for her challenge to Simon. The FEC said GOP Reps. Hank Brown of Colorado, running for an open seat, and Tom Tauke of Iowa, contesting incumbent Democrat Tom Harkin, also raised more than $1 million apiece last year. Gramm reported $6.1 million cash on hand going into 1990, the most of any candidate. Bradley, who faces no serious opposition, was second with $4.1 million. He also spent the most last year _ $2.8 million. The FEC report covered 31 incumbents and 29 challengers, plus 10 candidates in three open-seat races in Colorado, Idaho and New Hampshire. The agency said the candidates reported raising $62 million and spending $28 million during 1989. By comparison, candidates in 33 Senate races in 1984 had spent a little more than $35 million in 1983. The candidate receiving the most money from political action committees last year was Sen. Jay Rockefeller, D-W.Va. The FEC said he took in $830,200. Simon was second with $732,848, followed by Gramm with $715,313. A dozen candidates in all reported raising at least a half-million dollars each from PACs. In the same states six years ago, the FEC said, the top five PAC recipients received less than $400,000 each from the committees. The agency said only 12 candidates raised over $1 million in 1983 compared with 22 last year. Three spent more than $1 million, compared with nine in 1989; and six had more than $1 million in cash going into the 1984 election year, half the number with that amount on hand for 1990.

DOC.HEAD: Tanker Skipper Turns to College Classmate For Legal Help
DOC.TEXT: When Joseph Hazelwood became the target of criminal charges in the Exxon Valdez oil spill, the tanker captain turned to a former maritime college classmate who had become a lawyer. The lawyer brought in a friend from his law school days, and they then turned to a former law partner of Alaska's governor for help. They'll all be on center stage this week to open their defense of Hazelwood, portrayed in three weeks of prosecution testimony and questioning as a drunk who let his ship get away from him. Hazelwood, 43, of Huntington, N.Y., is charged with a felony and three misdemeanors in the March 24 grounding that caused the nation's worst oil spill. He could receive up to 7\ years in prison and $61,000 in fines. His ship struck a reef outside normal shipping lanes and gushed nearly 11 million gallons of Alaska crude oil into scenic Prince William Sound, coating hundreds of miles of shore with black goo. Hazelwood is the only person criminally charged in the disaster. At the counsel table with Hazelwood in Superior Court is Michael Chalos, 42, an exuberant advocate whose knowledge of nautical terminology and navigational logic has proved invaluable. Chalos was born in Chios, Greece. When he was 8, his family moved to Long Beach, N.Y. He attended the state university's Maritime College at Fort Schuyler, where he met Hazelwood. ``He was in the class of '68 and I was in the class of '70,'' said Chalos. ``We both played lacrosse.'' They became friends and stayed in touch. Chalos worked as a seaman for three years before entering Fordham University Law School, from which he graduated in 1975. His New York firm, Chalos, English & Brown, now has 20 lawyers. He has used Hazelwood as an expert witness in maritime cases. A member of the firm and of the Hazelwood defense team is Thomas Russo, 43, a former chief assistant district attorney in New York. Russo and Chalos met at Fordham and kept in touch. ``Mike and I had talked for many years about working together,'' Russo recalled. ``He thought I might like the change of working in a nice, quiet maritime practice.'' They joined forces two years ago. ``Then, he calls and tells me we're representing Captain Hazelwood.'' They needed an Alaska lawyer to augment the team and, after much research, chose Dick Madson of Fairbanks. Madson, 54, a native of Keewatin, Minn., and a 21-year resident of Fairbanks, brings to the defense knowledge of Alaska law and an insider's view of the state's political backbone. His longtime partner was Steve Cowper, Alaska's governor. Madson moved to Alaska with his wife and three children after graduating from William Mitchell College of Law in St. Paul, Minn. He has an undergraduate degree in mining engineering. He was one of Alaska's first public defenders and since has handled a wide array of criminal cases. ``We recognize this is a case in Alaska and you can't get more Alaskan than Dick,'' said Russo. ``He has the Alaska perspective.'' Madson's folksy witticisms often amuse the jury while bringing stern reprimands from Judge Karl Johnstone. Russo said he sees the Hazelwood trial as a diversionary tactic by state and federal agencies to play down their own potential culpability. He calls Hazelwood a scapegoat. ``It's about money,'' Chalos said. ``There's a lot of money involved. You've got plaintiffs with lawsuits involving billions of dollars.'' Madson said: ``The heart of it is a political trial.'' Chalos would not discuss the financial arrangement the lawyers have with Hazelwood. Hazelwood has been reviled by Alaskans because of the spill, but his lawyers see a shift in attitude. ``I was walking down the street with him this week,'' Madson said, ``and a woman stopped her car and yelled out `Is that Captain Hazelwood?' I said, `No, that's not him.' Then she shouted, `I love him!' I shouted back: `That's him!'''

Here is a transcript of a joint press conference held by President Bush and West German Chancelor Helmut Kohl. PRESIDENT BUSH: Barbara and I met February 24th and 25th here at Camp David with Helmut Kohl, the Chancellor of the Federal Republic of Germany, and his wife Annalore (sp) and we were just delighted to have them here. The Chancellor and I had an opportunity to talk at length about recent political developments in Europe and about East-West relations. And I am pleased to say that we share similar views on the most fundamental issues. We both welcome the prospect of further movement toward German unification, beginning with the steps toward economic and monetary union that are proposed for the period immediately following the elections in the GDR on March 18th. ``If events are moving faster than we expected, it just means that our common goal for all these years of German unity will be realized even sooner than had been hoped. We share a common belief that a unified Germany should remain a full member of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, including participation in its military structure. Now we agreed that US military forces should remain stationed in a united Germany and elsewhere in Europe, as a continuing guarantor of stability. ``The Chancellor and I are also in agreement that in a united -- in a unified state, the former territory of the GDR should have a special miliary status that would take into account the legitimate security interests of all interested countries, including those of the Soviet Union. At the same time, the Chancellor and I agree that we must continue to press hard for arms control efforts which would sharply reduce military forces in Europe from the Atlantic to the Urals. We want to work together to have a CFE agreement ready for signature this year at a summit meeting of all 35 CSCE member states. The summit could also endorse our proposal for CSCE guidelines on free elections to help show the way and protect the emerging democratic institutions of Eastern Europe. ``Chancellor Kohl and I had a good discussion on East-West relations. We both support Chairman Gorbachev's program of perestroika, his efforts to reform his country's political and enomic system. Chairman Gorbachev has shown true statemanship in respecting the will of the people in Eastern Europe in trying to build new relationships based on cooperation instead of coercion. Since those difficult days following World War II, when America joined hands with the German people in their effort to build a new state and a new society, the United States has been their partner in a common dream, and that dream was to build a free, democratic, and prosperous German republic committed to peace and working in close harmony with its closest neighbors. That enduring German-American partnership has never been stronger as Chancellor Kohl, the leader of one of the world's great democracies, steps toward a golden moment in the history of his nation. Mr. Chancellor, it was a pleasure to have you with us and now for your statement, sir.

DOC.HEAD: Suppression of Dissent Mars Image of Ivorian President
DOC.TEXT: President Felix Houphouet-Boigny, once praised as a peacemaker and the driving force of an agricultural power, increasingly has been targeted in complaints about police repression and a souring economy. Police in the past week have beaten and arrested hundreds of demonstrators who demanded the ouster of Africa's longest-serving president and an end to his one-party, conservative rule. The official media, which have built a personality cult around Houphouet-Boigny, have made no mention of the protests. Houphouet-Boigny chaired a Cabinet meeting during last week's unrest, but state media reported only that officials discussed the West African nation's economic crisis. Austerity measures that helped provoke the unrest were required by Western donors, who already have rescheduled the country's $12 billion debt. ``Our cup of anger overflowed when the last drop of water dribbled from the tap,'' a law student said, describing the scene one night last week in the communal bathroom of a student residence darkened by power cuts. The state-run power company said the cuts Feb. 19 were caused by an explosion at a transformer. No mention was made of the water shortage. Students and Radio Treichville, the name given to the well-informed rumor network, said workers forced to take 30 percent pay cuts caused the service disruptions as a protest. The methods used against protesters are not in the usual style of the 84-year-old president, who has led this nation of 11 million people since its independence from France in 1960. ``He has perfected the art of co-opting the opposition,'' said Laurent Gbabgo, an opposition leader. ``In the past, people did not feel badly governed because, if there was a problem, the government just bought it out. They had lots of money and just doled it out,'' he said. Houphouet-Boigny's government has not been above tough tactics. When it felt threatened by criticism from the university lecturers' union in 1987, it simply hijacked the body. Office holders were arrested for alleged embezzlement of funds and drafted into two years' military service. A hand-picked committee replaced them. But the economic problems have unearthed such dissent that Houphouet-Boigny called a national dialogue in September, and told delegates no holds were barred. It brought at least one demand he could not stomach, again from the university lecturers' union. Union president Marcel Ette urged creation of a multiparty democracy. The president responded that there would be no multiparty democracy in Ivory Coast, at least not in his lifetime. As other African dictators have done, he argued that a multiparty system would endanger national unity in a country still beset by tribal rivalries. ``The Ivory Coast Constitution allows political opposition. But things start happening if you try to insist on your rights,'' Gbagbo said in an interview. ``You and your friends get arrested. Your bank account gets frozen. Suddenly, business isn't good.'' Houphouet-Boigny vigorously encouraged agricultural production of the cash crops pushed by Western institutions in the 1960s and 1970s. While most of black Africa became net food importers following independence from European colonial powers, his efforts spurred Ivorian farmers to record production. Last year, amid a continuing slump in commodity prices, Ivory Coast produced a record 820,000 tons of cocoa, nine times what it produced in 1960 and nearly a third of world production. It is the world's biggest cocoa producer. But cocoa prices were slashed to half those of 1985. In October, Houphouet-Boigny was forced to abandon his promise to support prices for farmers, and he cut promised producer prices for cocoa and coffee in half. Critics like Gbagbo say the president is too old and set in his ways to look to industrialization and other routes to revive the economy. But Houphouet-Boigny looks more like a man in his 70s and appears alert, astute and far from ready to retire. ``The old regime is dying, but it's dying badly,'' Gbagbo complained. Its dying throes will come because Ivorians are being hit where it hurts most: in their pockets, he said. When wealthy Ivorians go to the bank to cash a $17,500 check, the liquidity crisis forces the banks to tell them to make the check out for $88, he said. A government clerk feeling the pinch of a pay cut expressed it another way: ``Last year I gave my son a few francs for lunch and he could have a hot stew and grilled bananas. The same money today buys only the bananas. And I don't have the extra money to buy him the stew.''

X X X statement, sir. CHANCELLOR KOHL (through interpreter): (Translator starts in progress) -- the reception here in Camp David. The atmosphere, the climate of our meeting is symbolic of the excellent German-American relations. In particular now, when the day of unity is drawing near for us Germans, we are conscious with profound gratitude of the fact that all of this would not have been possible without the close friendship and the confident partnership with the United States of America. ``In the spirit of this friendship, the two of us, Mr. President, in the course of these hours in Camp David, we have discussed a vast list of political issues. In the center of our conversations was the future of the transatlantic relations and, embedded therein, the path of the Germans towards national unity. Against the background of historic changes on the European continent, we have reconfirmed our common beliefs. First, the alliance of the free democracies in Europe and North America, and included therein the German-American partnership, are of fundamental importance for peace and security. This is true now; this will be true in future. Second, the security link between North America and Europe is and continues to be, and in the future, for us Germans -- that is to say, also for a united Germany -- of vital importance. That is why we need the presence of our American friends in Europe, in Germany, and that includes the presence of American forces. Also, for a united Germany in the future, maintaining the friendship with the United States of America and the expansion of relations with them will be an important task. ``We are happy about the ever closer economic cooperation and economic exchange, exchange in the fields of science and culture, and about the ever more meaningful meetings between people, in particular of the young generation. We are convinced that transatlantic relations must systematically be expanded in all fields. It is the common security in the alliance which is part of this, of the ever closer contacts between the European Community, including political cooperation, and the United States. And this includes also our joint efforts to make our way towards a European peace order within the framework of the CSCE. Seeing the major changes in Central Europe, East Europe, Southeast Europe, the European Community continues to be an indispensable anchor of European civility. ``That is why we, the Federal Republic of Germany, in particular myself, do not only want to expand European integration but we want to accelerate this process wherever possible. Beyond the big internal market which is to be achieved on the 31st of December, 1992, beyond the economic and monetary union, our primordial aim continues to be political union in Europe. That was the objective of the treaties of Rome and nothing has changed in that area. It is our joint interest that the reform policy in Central, East and Southeast Europe and, in particular, the policy led by Secretary General Gorbachev and the Soviet Union will be successful. Europe and North America are and continue to be open for cooperation as partners, in particular with the reform states. And I welcome particularly what you have just said about the subject, Mr. President. ``And because of our conversations, we're also agreed that disarmament negotiations must energetically be pursued and be led to a success. On the path towards German unity, ladies and gentlemen, what we need in particular now is reason and good judgment. We Germans walk along this path with a particular responsibility in the center of Europe. And we're doing so, if you like, along two tracks which are of equal importance. On the one hand, we are leading intensive talks with GDR, and at present we will, in particular, have to concentrate on the customs union and the Economic Community. On the other hand, we do have to consider that the link with our transatlantic partners, that European unity and comprehensive cooperation between East and West are being linked up with the development. We do respect the legitimate security interests of all states and we respect people's feelings, especially the feelings of our neighbors. ``And I am saying this particularly addressing our Polish neighbors. The border question will be settled definitely by a freely elected, all-German government, and a freely elected all-German parliament. But let me repeat here what I have recently said in Paris already -- it was in January of this year -- nobody has any intention of linking the question of national unity with changes of existing borders.

DOC.HEAD: Sullivan Finds His Voice With Anti-Smoking Remarks
DOC.TEXT: Louis Sullivan, after a shaky start as the nation's top health official, has seized the anti-smoking campaign as his own, winning kudos from Congress and grabbing headlines with talk of ``blood money'' and ``trading death for corporate profits.'' Following the well-worn path of previous federal health officials, Sullivan, the secretary of Health and Human Services, has cranked up the war of words against tobacco companies to new heights. ``He certainly has found an area where he has been willing to be outspoken and has taken the leadership,'' said Rep. Henry Waxman, D-Calif., chairman of the House Energy and Commerce health subcommittee. But some say smoking is a safe issue, since Sullivan isn't attacking tobacco subsidies or proposing a ban on advertising. And they say Sullivan, who for nearly a year has run the federal department with the largest budget, has yet to show such bold leadership on the larger issues confronting the administration, including the nation's soaring health-care bill. Sullivan first stepped out on the smoking issue Jan. 18 when he criticized R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Co.'s plan to target blacks with a new cigarette brand called Uptown. The next day the company canceled plans for the new product, but Sullivan promised to continue his attack on the tobacco industry. Last week, Sullivan called on athletes and athletic associations to reject tobacco company sponsorships _ and he didn't mince words: ``This blood money should not be used to foster a misleading impression that smoking is compatible with good health.'' Appearing before the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee a few days earlier, he said ``it is morally wrong to promote a product which, when used as intended, causes death, trading death for corporate profits.'' In the wake of reports that Reynolds had considered marketing a new cigarette brand called Dakota to young women with no more than a high school education, Sullivan said such advertising was ``dishonest, irresponsible and unconscionable.'' Before he seized the anti-smoking issue, Sullivan had been on the defensive for most of his first year on the job. First he angered right-to-life groups with comments implying that he supported abortion rights. He quickly retreated and said he supported President Bush's anti-abortion stand. Later he raised another storm when he endorsed local community efforts to experiment with needle-exchange programs to help stem the spread of AIDS. He later backed off that statement as well. His bold anti-smoking campaign, however, is helping to turn around his image as a fumbling newcomer to Washington politics. ``It increases his profile in the administration and in Congress, and that can do nothing but help,'' said Edmund Haislmaier, health care policy analyst at the Heritage Foundation, a conservative think tank. ``The real test, though, is how effective he's going to be ... in advocating reform in the programs in his department,'' Haislmaier said. The effects of an anti-smoking effort are ``very small. It will have a positive impact, but how much and when is a very debatable question and does not really deal with the major health care financing issues HHS is involved in.'' On the tobacco issue, Sullivan is following a trail blazed by previous public health officials dating back to the first surgeon general, Luther Terry, who put out the initial surgeon general's report on smoking in 1964. Former Surgeon General C. Everett Koop, before he left office last summer, was the nation's leading anti-smoking crusader for most of the 1980s. With no statutory authority or budget, Koop used his post as bully pulpit to preach the dangers of smoking, endorsing a ban on cigarette advertising and declaring nicotine to be as addictive as heroin. Before him, Joseph Califano, secretary of what then was called the Department of Health, Education and Welfare, campaigned aggressively against smoking and drew a lot of fire in the process. He angered many members of Congress from Southern tobacco-growing states. Sullivan said he has gotten ``not one iota of pressure'' from the administration to back off from his campaign. ``I've gotten support and commendations from not only members of Congress but also members of the administration,'' he said. But Sullivan has refrained from being anything more than an anti-smoking advocate. Asked whether the government should cut off subsidies to tobacco growers, or whether cigarette taxes should be raised, he says those are not decisions for him to make. ``My role is to put the facts out ... to advocate,'' he said. Waxman said that while he applauds Sullivan's anti-smoking leadership, ``I hope now to see him follow up his statements with support for legislation.'' The California Democrat plans to introduce a bill focusing on regulation of tobacco promotions and advertising, along with stronger warning labels on cigarette packages. Sen. Edward Kennedy, D-Mass., introduced an anti-smoking measure that focuses chiefly on education efforts and regulation of tobacco product ingredients. Sullivan said that while he supported the intent of most of the legislation, he believes it duplicates efforts already under way. Though Sullivan has always opposed smoking, his campaign against tobacco companies is relatively new for him. In September 1987, while serving on an advisory board of the National Cancer Institute, Sullivan presented to the board a report on a National Black Leadership Initiative on Cancer that advised education as the key weapon rather than ``a frontal attack on the tobacco companies.'' Asked about this change of strategy, Sullivan pointed to a new government report estimating that smoking costs the nation about $52 billion annually, largely in increased health-care and insurance costs.

DOC.HEAD: Pertini, Former Socialist Preisdent of Italy Dies
DOC.TEXT: Sandro Pertini, the beloved former Socialist president, symbol of integrity and World War II hero, died in his sleep at the age of 93 and was eulogized Sunday for his honesty and forthright style. Pertini died late Saturday at his apartment in central Rome, Italian media reported. No cause of death was given, but Pertini suffered a concussion after falling and hitting his head in early February. He refused to be taken to a hospital, insisting he wanted to die at home. The Cabinet, led by Premier Giulio Andreotti, met in special session Sunday and ordered flags flown at half-staff during the next two days. In accordance with Pertini's wishes, no state funeral will be held. Pertini will be cremated in Rome on Monday morning and his ashes taken on the presidential plane to his birthplace outside Savona, near Genoa, for a private funeral service, the ANSA news agency reported. Also in keeping with Pertini's wishes, his successor as president, Francesco Cossiga, was the only visitor to the apartment on Sunday, paying a half-hour call representing ``all Italians.'' ``The nation is lucky to be defended by men such as Sandro Pertini,'' Cossiga said. Pope John Paul, in a condolence message, recalled his ``warm friendship'' with Pertini, especially after the pontiff was shot in 1981 and Pertini kept a vigil outside John Paul's hospital room. Pertini once joked to reporters that he didn't know whether there was a heaven, but if one existed he was sure to get in and ``Pope Wojtyla (John Paul) will give me a push.'' A founder of the Italian Socialist Party who spent nearly 10 years in fascist prisons, Pertini served as a president from 1978 to 1985, restoring prestige to the largely ceremonial post. He served during Italy's successful fight against urban terrorism, boosting morale and instilling a sense of pride. In the presidency, Pertini replaced Giovanni Leone, forced to resign following unproven allegations of financial wrongdoing. Installed at age 81, Pertini said: ``I am old, but I am not blind, deaf or dumb.'' Born outside the Italian Riviera town of Savona on Sept. 25, 1896, Pertini studied law and political science before fighting in World War I. As a young man, he played a major role in building the Italian Socialist Party. During the rise of fascism following World War I, Pertini was imprisoned but escaped to France. In 1929, during the regime of dictator Benito Mussolini, he was captured in northern Italy and imprisoned again. Pertini spent nearly 10 years in prison before he escaped to lead a resistance movement in northern Italy. The Nazis sentenced him to death in 1943 but he eluded capture. Pertini was elected to Parliament after the war's end and re-elected in the decades that followed. As president, Pertini refused to live in the Quirinal Palace, keeping his apartment at the Trevi Fountain in Central Rome. During his frequent walks, Pertini often stopped to talk to passers-by _ a nightmare for his security detail. Pertini is survived by his wife, Carla.

DOC.HEAD: High Court to Hear Case on Whether Post Office Property is Public Forum
DOC.TEXT: Free speech advocates say access to the public soapbox is at stake Monday in a case before the U.S. Supreme Court involving two Lyndon LaRouche followers who tried to solicit support on a post office sidewalk. The court's decision will either broaden access to government property for the purpose of free speech or further restrict what constitutes a public forum. The case will also allow the court to clarify conflicting rulings from federal appeals courts on the government's ban on soliciting on Postal Service property. Groups such as the Hare Krishnas, conservative Christians, the AFL-CIO and newspapers have filed friend-of-the-court briefs urging that free speech rights be expanded. ``The public forum doctrine is for the little person,'' said attorney Jay Sekulow. ``Missionaries and evangelicals cannot afford full-page newspaper ads. They can afford a sidewalk to talk to people about the gospel.'' Sekulow represents Marsha Kokinda and Kevin Pearl, LaRouche volunteers who were convicted of violating a regulation against ``soliciting, electioneering, collecting debts, vending and advertising'' on Postal Service property. LaRouche, a political extremist and sometime presidential candidate, is serving a 15-year prison term for his 1988 conviction on fraud and conspiracy charges. Prosecutors accused him of conspiring to accept millions of dollars in loans from political supporters he had no intention of repaying. Courts have wrestled with a number of cases in recent years seeking to define a ``public forum'' where speech cannot be unreasonably restricted. Judges have been asked to decide, for example, whether taxpayer-financed airline terminals or private shopping malls can bar people from handing out leaflets or asking for contributions. Kokinda and Pearl chose as their soapbox a narrow strip of sidewalk leading between the parking lot and the doors of the tiny post office on a busy highway in this Washington suburb. They were arrested in 1986 after they refused to stop soliciting contributions and distributing literature from a table. Kokinda was fined $50 and sentenced to 10 days in jail. Pearl was fined $100. Their convictions were thrown out by the 4th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in 1989. The Supreme Court will hear arguments Monday and is expected to issue a decision by July. In appealing to the high court, the government argues that there is a difference between a city sidewalk and one located entirely on Postal Service property. It also argues that picketing, handing out pamphlets and soliciting interfere with postal business. And a Justice Department attorney will argue Monday that free speech is limited to some extent on all government property. The 4th Circuit ruling is binding in Maryland, North Carolina, South Carolina, Virginia and West Virginia. But two other appeals courts have upheld the ban on soliciting on post office property, so there is no nationwide standard for the Postal Service to follow. David Liberman, an attorney for the International Society of Krishna Consciousness, said the Postal Service is isolating its property from other government buildings that are considered public. ``Where do you find the people these days? A suburban post office is where you find the people. If this is not a forum, then the government can exclude everything from that place,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Cambodian Resistance Faces Major Defeat; Peace talks to Begin
DOC.TEXT: Guerrilla commanders admitted Sunday they have suffered major battlefield losses to government troops and blamed a halt in weapons shipments from China, their main supplier. It remains unclear if the cut-off, confirmed by Western diplomats in Bangkok, is because of logistical problems or a policy decision by the Chinese government. On Friday, government troops rolled into the strategic, guerrilla-held town of Svay Chek. Guerrilla leaders said Sunday they were unable to make a stand at a second important town, Tmar Puok, because of a shortage of ammunition. ``We cannot defend Tmar Puok. It looks very bad right now,'' said a senior commander of the Khmer People's National Liberation Front. The front is allied with the Communist Khmer Rouge and a group loyal to guerrilla coalition leader Prince Norodom Sihanouk. The commander said the front abandoned its civilian administration headquarters in Tmar Puok, which had served 50,000 civilians as a ``liberated zone'' since guerrillas seized it in September. The guerrilla coalition stepped up its offensive against the government in the fall after Vietnam claimed to have withdrawn its last troops and ended an 11-year military intervention. Repeated attempts to establish a formula for peace have failed. A plan that would have the United Nations run Cambodia until elections is expected to be discussed in three days of informal talks that begin Monday in Jakarta, Indonesia. A Western analyst on the Thai border estimated 15,000 civilians would flee to the Thai frontier if Tmar Puok fell. Thousands have already left areas of fighting and were moving closer to the border, analysts said. The guerrillas seized a large swath of territory along the Thai border following the Vietnamese withdrawal. The reversal came as Sihanouk ended 11 years of exile on Friday, saying he would live in villages northeast of the current fighting. Officials and refugees at Site B, located along the Thai-Cambodian border, said Sihanouk's return was a boost to morale among the more than 50,000 camp residents. ``We'll win now,'' 51-year-old refugee Kim Lay said Sunday at Site B, the principal refugee camp for Sihanouk's followers. But a recent defector from Khmer Rouge forces at the camp said the group's fighting ability was hurt by a sharp drop in weapons and other supplies from China about two months ago. ``Before, China used to support us 100 percent, now it's only 50 percent. There is even a lack of food _ its not like it was before,'' said Hem Khaem, a 25-year-old former Khmer Rouge company commander. ``We were told in meetings that we had to save everything. ...The principle was one bullet should kill one person and if you couldn't get a good shot, don't shoot.'' The front received its last shipment of Chinese weapons in early December, according to diplomatic and guerrilla sources. Some guerrilla commanders have said the cut-off was to force the coalition to work more closely together. The front and Sihanouk's forces are deeply suspicious of the Khmer Rouge, which killed hundreds of thousands of Cambodians during its three-year rule. The Vietnamese invasion of 1978 ousted the Khmer Rouge. The peace plan on the agenda in Jakarta, proposed by Australia and supported by the five permanent members of the U.N. Security Council, appears to offer the best hope of ending the bloody conflict. Attending the talks will be the four Cambodian factions; Vietnam; Laos; France; and representatives of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations _Brunei, Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore and Thailand.

DOC.HEAD: Wildlife Officers Push Co-Existence With Mountain Lions
DOC.TEXT: People have been moving into mountain lion country in Coal Creek Canyon west of Boulder for 30 years, but now there are enough people there that the big cats are becoming accustomed to them _ and getting bolder. Pets have been killed there before, but so far this winter, mountain lions have killed three dogs on their owners' property. One was leashed and one was in an enclosure. One of the dogs was a Labrador retriever and one a German shepherd. The owner of a Doberman pinscher heard a commotion behind his house and found a mountain lion attacking the dog. When confronted by the human, the cat calmly walked away. The dog was hospitalized. Twenty miles from the canyon, a mountain lion last week apparently killed three llamas at a ranch. A private hunter killed a mountain lion in the canyon. Residents fear the next victims may be children walking to school bus stops before sunup _ prime hunting time for the big cats, also known as cougars or pumas. ``We're not trying to get people paranoid, but they are living in lion habitat. They can be taught to be lion smart, just as city kids have to be taught to be street smart. If kids are too young to be lion smart, they shouldn't be outside alone,'' said Kathi Demarest, a state wildlife biologist. ``We are not going to kill lions just because people are afraid of them. We are not going back to the 1870s when lions were killed for a bounty.'' Several hundred people live in the canyon on scattered home sites. Wildlife officials have begun a series of meetings with them to educate them about living in lion country. ``People tell us they live in the Colorado mountains because of the wildlife. My goal is to teach people to appreciate the wildlife and live with it,'' Demarest said. She estimated five to 45 pmas remain in the canyon area. The cats are tawny colored with a black tip on the tail. An adult can grow to more than 7 feet from nose to tip of tail and weigh upwards of 150 pounds. Its method of attack is to lie in ambush, then leap on the back of its prey and bite through the skull or neck for the kill. Their main prey is deer. Kristi Coughlon, a state wildlife manager in the Boulder district, said there have been three confirmed mountain lion kills of dogs, another dog injured and several unconfirmed pet kills and missing pets this winter. However, coyotes also take dogs and cats and landowners kill dogs, she said. If any of the mountain lions become aggressive toward humans, state trackers can be brought in to kill them, she said. Some people have obtained special state permits to kill cougars that have killed dogs. Until recent years, there had never been a confirmed, unprovoked mountain lion attack on a human in this country. That changed with mass human encroachment upon lion habitat. A child was killed by a lion in Montana and a child was injured and another killed in an Orange County, Calif., wildlife refuge, authorities said. There have also been mountain lion attacks in Arizona and Texas. Parents ``must start taking their kids to the bus stop, install a light at the bus stop, clear brush away from the area, don't let kids play alone near brush and install fenced play areas for kids,'' Demarest said. Many city people unwittingly do things that put them ``on a clear collision course with wildlife,'' such as putting out salt blocks for deer, she said. ``They're just setting themselves up for lion trouble,'' she said. Mountain residents should bring their pets in at night along with pet food, and not leave out garbage, because it attracts wild animals, she said. ``We hope to develop a system that has lions tolerating people and people tolerating lions,'' Demarest said.

DOC.HEAD: Retired General Harbors Bitterness Over Iran-Contra Affair
DOC.TEXT: Richard V. Secord refers to the Iran-Contra prosecutors as ``this gang'' and yearns to go after the lawyers who prosecuted him for his role in setting up a private network to supply arms to the Nicaraguan Contras. The prosecutors are none too fond of the retired Air Force major general, either, and would like to reinstate charges dropped in a plea bargain agreement. Still unclear is what impact the mutual rancor will have on Secord's role in the case against former national security adviser John M. Poindexter. ``As far as I know I'm not on the witness list yet,'' Secord said in an interview in which he vented his anger at Iran-Contra independent counsel Lawrence Walsh and his staff. ``A day of reckoning is coming for this gang,'' said Secord. But the retired military officer also conceded he's had little success raising money for the fund he established to ``go after'' Walsh and challenge the Ethics in Government Act. Secord said his ultimate goal is to overturn the law which authorizes appointment of special prosecutors. Secord, 57, a native of Columbus, Ohio, flew bombing missions in Southeast Asia during the Vietnam conflict. He held a number of high-ranking positions at the Pentagon before he retired. A short, square-jawed man with a wry sense of humor and a blunt way of talking, Secord can also be pugnacious when challenged. After he pleaded guilty to making a false statement to congressional investigators, he was expected to play a role in the prosecution of Poindexter on charges of concealing facts from Congress and lying about a 1985 shipment of Hawk missiles to Iran _ a shipment in which Secord was involved. As part of a plea bargain agreement with prosecutors, Secord agreed to cooperate fully on future cases. Eleven other criminal charges were dropped and he walked away from the federal courthouse on Jan 24 with a suspended sentence after paying $50 in court costs. The day after Secord was sentenced by U.S. District Judge Aubrey Robinson, he filed an appeal on the grounds that Walsh didn't have jurisdiction to prosecute for an offense arising out of Secord's testimony to Congress. Walsh's staff retaliated by claiming Secord acted in ``bad faith'' by agreeing to plead guilty while all the time planning to challenge the plea. Prosecutors asked Robinson to reinstate the 11 charges against Secord. Asked why he filed an appeal _ and risked facing charges again _ Secord said, ``My wife asked me the same question _ she just wants it to end.'' In the final analysis, Secord said he wants to repair his reputation. ``My reputation has been so damaged by the special prosecutor ... This isn't a special prosecutor; it's a P.R. outfit.'' Secord said he hasn't seen the prosecutors in a month. ``I haven't even seen one of them,'' though he said he had talked with them earlier. That doesn't mean he won't be called to testify in a Poindexter trial. ``With these guys (prosecutors) you never know,'' said the man who set up a private network to supply weapons to the Nicaraguan Contras at a time when Congress had banned official U.S. military aid for the rebels. Secord also arranged for the shipment of weapons to Iran and directed companies into which profits from those sales were placed. Sam Witucki, a spokeswoman for Walsh, said prosecutors don't discuss witnesses and other details in advance of a trial. As for the upcoming Poindexter trial, Secord said he didn't have any contact with Poindexter about the shipment of Hawk missiles to Iran in November 1985. ``His name was never mentioned,'' he said. Secord said he tried to arrange the shipment of the Hawks from Israel through Portugal to Iran at North's behest. ``North called after talking to (former national security adviser Robert) McFarlane,'' he said. When McFarlane resigned as the NSC adviser in December 1985, he was replaced by Poindexter. Secord said the first time he met with Poindexter was in January 1986. ``The Hawk shipment took place on McFarlane's watch _ not Poindexter's,'' Secord said.

DOC.HEAD: Anti-Semitism in Soviet Union Increases, Prompting Jewish Exodus
DOC.TEXT: Increasingly open acts of anti-Semitism have scared thousands of Soviet Jews out of their homeland, where they fear becoming targets of ethnic violence. Many immigrants arriving in Israel speak of their fears, even though most say they have not witnessed anti-Semitic acts or been personally threatened. But they have read widely circulated anti-Semitic magazines and have seen reports in newspapers or on television referring to plans for pogroms by anti-Jewish groups. ``Once, we laughed at the rumors that there may be a pogrom,'' said Elena Kopelevitch, a 30-year-old pianist from Odessa who arrived in Israel two weeks ago. ``But now, there's an anti-Jewish hysteria, and it's like a snowball.'' Israeli officials expect as many as 750,000 Jews to eventually leave the Soviet Union because of more liberal exit policies. While Jews also are leaving to seek economic opportunity or because they doubt the new freedom in the Soviet Union will last, racism is another factor. Immigrants noted attacks on Armenians in the Azerbaijani capital of Baku in January and in Uzbekistan's Fergana valley, where Uzbeks last June killed more than 100 Meshkhetian Turks. In such cases, authorities failed to protect the minorities, the Soviet Jews say. There is widespread fear the Jewish minority would not be protected in case of trouble, they say. ``We have not witnessed any direct anti-Semitism but we lived in fear,'' said Elena Kopelevitch's brother Danny, a student. At the house of friends, a mixed Armenian-Jewish family, Ms. Kopelevitch said he met an Armenian refugee from Baku, an 85-year-old woman who ``looked terrible ... she was covered with blue marks and bruises from beatings.'' ``I'm still trembling as I recall it. We did not want to wait for the same fate,'' she said. Anti-Semitism is not a new experience for Soviet Jews. In the late 1940s and early 1950s, Josef Stalin ordered leading Soviet Jewish writers and actors killed and initiated anti-Semitic trials. An anti-Zionist campaign, with clear anti-Semitic overtones, also followed the Soviet Union's break in diplomatic ties with Israel after the 1967 Middle East war. Much of the government-sponsored anti-Semitism has disappeared in the five years of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's reforms, but liberalized rules also have unleashed grassroots anti-Semitism. Vladimir Nosenko of Moscow's Insitute of World Economy and International Relations, visiting Israel, pointed to unofficial anti-Semitism as a cause for Jewish fears. ``Imagine a country where emerging movements and parties accuse the Jews of causing all the trials and tribulations of the natives, and call for the extermination of `Jewish dominance' for the sake of a better future,'' he wrote in the Jerusalem Post. Nosenko said that several periodicals ``specialize in publishing material which plays on anti-Jewish emotion.'' Much of the open anti-Semitism is spearheaded by factions of National-Patriotic Pamyat Front. A Pamyat manifesto reported by the newpaper ``Soviet Circus'' in October said Stalin's repressions in the 1930s were ``Zionist genocide (that) killed more people in our country than in all the wars of mankind.'' Last week the weekly Literaturnaya Gazeta said Moscow prosecutors have begun criminal proceedings against Pamyat on charges of ``inciting national and racial hatred and strife.'' ``It is very frightening to be a Jew in the Soviet Union these days,'' said Kira Nefyodova, a chemist from Leningrad. Soviet Jews were particularly worried by a Jan. 18 attack on April, a liberal group of Soviet writers. About 50 Pamyat activists holding signs saying ``Moscow is not Tel Aviv'' broke into an April meeting. According to a tape transcript printed by the liberal Ogonyok weekly, a Pamyat member who identified himself as Smirnov shouted at the writers through a megaphone: ``Yids and Masons, get out of the hall ... comrade Jews, leave the hall ... your time has ran out, and neither police, nor KGB or the party will help you. Now we shall rule the country and you, aliens, get out to Israel.'' Participants in the April meeting later complained that police took no action. Nobel Peace Prize winner Elie Wiesel, who visited Moscow last month, has said that in his six visits he had never seen Jews ``living and dwelling in such fear.'' Wiesel called on Gorbachev to personally condemn the growing anti-Semitism, but no government condemnation followed. In private meetings, Soviet leaders assured some Western guests they would not tolerate any pogroms. Maya Kaganskaya, a Soviet-born author and researcher on anti-Semitism affiliated with Jerusalem's Hebrew University, said Soviet authorities cannot openly condemn anti-Semitic forces that seem to enjoy mass support. ``These people are supported by hundreds of thousands ... while there is no social base for the so-called liberals,'' she said in an interview. ``Therefore the authorities want to the remove explosive material, the Jews, by encouraging them to leave,'' she said. They don't want Russia covered with Jewish blood.''

DOC.HEAD: Rocky Statue May Lose Bout With Art Museum
DOC.TEXT: It looks as if Rocky Balboa has lost his bout with Philadelphia's art museum. The 8-foot, 6-inch statue of the fictional South Philadelphia palooka is scheduled to leave its spot atop the Philadelphia Museum of Art steps Monday for its former home at the Spectrum arena, museum spokeswoman Sandra Horrocks said Sunday. The statue of Rocky in boxing trunks and gloves, his arms raised in triumph, was moved from the Spectrum for the filming of the latest chapter in Sylvester Stallone's ``Rocky'' saga. Producers of ``Rocky V'' had agreed to remove the statue, a prop made for ``Rocky III,'' by Monday. But Stallone and fans of the underdog boxer tried to persuade the museum to keep the bronze cast on the spot made so famous in the original ``Rocky'' that tourists regularly run up the steps and hop around the plaza in Rocky fashion. Polls by a local TV station and a newspaper show residents about equally split on the issue. Mayor W. Wilson Goode came out in favor of leaving the statue put, saying it serves as a great tourist attraction. Stallone hired a lawyer, former state boxing commissioner James Binns, to try to persuade the Fairmount Park Commission, which oversees the museum, to allow the statue to stay. Binns was returning from Venezuela on Sunday and could not immediately be reached for comment. But art museum officials say the statue is out of place. President Robert Montgomery Scott said it looks puny in front of the big Greco-Roman building and its columns. Art museum officials said the statue was to be moved by Jan. 31, but that deadline was extended to allow additional filming for the movie. The statue has been moved between the sports arena and the museum for almost eight years. It was made by the A. Thomas Schomberg Foundry in 1981 for the ``Rocky'' sequel and left there after the movie opened in 1982. That time, museum officials said Stallone failed to remove the statue as agreed, and the museum had to pay $12,000 to move it to the Spectrum.

DOC.HEAD: Strikers UMW Miners Return to Work Monday
DOC.TEXT: Miners return to work Monday at Pittston Coal Group after a violent 10-month strike in Virginia, Kentucky and West Virginia, with both sides saying it will take time for tensions to ease. The 1,700 miners, who had been fighting the company as well as the replacement workers and supervisors who kept it running during the strike, on Feb. 19 ratified a settlement reached New Year's Eve in Washington. Some miners returned to work Friday, but officials said most will be coming back for the first time on Monday. ``It's going to be odd going back,'' miner Buford Mullins said. ``I don't think things can be as they were before the strike. It's going to take a while.'' Pittston President Michael Odom said, ``There will be some tensions we will have to deal with.'' But he said the union employees struck with enthusiasm and probably will come back to work with enthusiasm. Violence erupted sporadically during the strike. Replacement workers and supervisors were often pelted with rocks as they drove to work and verbally abused when they went to town. The new contract gives union members the job security and health and retirement benefits they sought and gives Pittston the ability to run the mines seven days a week.

The Captain Has Put on the No-Smoking Sign _ Forever
DOC.TEXT: A smoking ban on virtually all domestic U.S. flights took effect Sunday amid both relief and grumbling, and the phrase ``Smoking or non-smoking?'' all but disappeared from the lips of ticket agents. ``If the plane starts to go down, I'm lighting one up,'' said Dave Noeth of New York City, a traveler at LaGuardia Airport. The federal ban, in force since 1988 on flights of less than two hours, now applies to 99.8 percent of domestic flights _ the only exception being flights to Alaska and Hawaii of more than six hours. Overseas fights are not affected. ``It's wonderful. It's for the health of everyone,'' said Eastern Airlines flight attendant Nancy Roberson of Charleston, S.C. ``I think there are more pleased people than not. All the passengers tell me about it.'' Michael Barnett, an Eastern ticket agent in Miami, said the elimination of smoking and non-smoking sections made his life a bit easier. ``Now we just issue seats,'' he said. Supporters of the ban say separate smoking sections do not adequately shield non-smoking passengers and crew members from cigarette smoke. Critics argue that smokers' rights are being trampled on. ``I don't think it's fair,'' said Gail Fiore of Huntington, N.Y., as she arrived at LaGuardia. ``I pay the same fare as a non-smoker and there should be a section for it. They're giving all the non-smokers all the rights and taking away all of ours.'' Added her husband, Hugo: ``Even in the service they gave you a 10-minute smoke break.'' Other smokers took a more resigned approach, even if nicotine withdrawal pangs are likely to bring new meaning to the term white-knuckle flying. ``If they say you don't smoke, you don't smoke,'' said Rich Meadows of Ridgecrest, Calif., as he awaited a Chicago-bound flight at Los Angeles International Airport. ``I don't care for it, but that's the way it goes. I'll just take some chewing tobacco, which makes the stewardesses mad. It's pretty disgusting, but it's something to do.'' Dan Lauria, a spokesman for the Tobacco Institute, a lobbying group, said last week that he had fielded many calls from ``miserable'' smokers. ``We are telling the people the law is the law,'' he said. ``We're telling people not to smoke in the bathroom. It's dangerous to the plane.'' Longtime smoker Joanne Sharples of Omaha, Neb., arriving in Miami, said she managed not to light up during the flight. ``After about three hours you get those anxiety pangs. But I've gone eight hours,'' she said. Mrs. Sharples, who said she has tried four times to quit smoking and plans to try again, said she understands non-smokers' desire to breathe clean air. ``I wish they would do the same thing for women who wear an abundance of perfume,'' she said. ``I can understand certainly a smoke-free America, a drug-free America and a perfume-free America!'' Matthew Bowen, who was traveling from Atlanta to Norfolk, Va., to see his grandchildren, said smokers must lobby to protect smoking areas. He said airlines would listen if smokers threatened to take their money to competitors. ``I've smoked three cigarettes this morning just waiting for the plane when I usually would smoke one,'' he said. He joked that he was ``storing up.''

DOC.HEAD: Military Proposes New Uniforms to Change Image
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS new 8th graf to UPDATE with police also to get new uniforms; pickup 8th graf pvs, `The new...' ADDS 3 grafs at end of story to UPDATE with details about protest.
DOC.TEXT: The armed forces will receive new uniforms as part of an effort to dissociate them from the repressive rule of Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu, authorities were quoted as saying Sunday. The defense minister, Lt. Gen. Victor A. Stanculescu, told the daily Romania Libera newspaper the uniforms would help give soldiers a new identity. The military kept order during the repressive 24-year tenure of Ceausescu but sided with civilians during the revolt that toppled him in December. An officer displayed the new uniforms for different branches of the armed forces Sunday on a television program devoted to military affairs. Among other changes, the new army officers' uniforms have soft epaulets similar to those used in the West, rather than the stiff, detachable shoulder boards that are the style in Warsaw Pact countries. Soldiers going on public patrols will be assigned smart belted green jackets with shirts and ties, rather than the pullovers and simple jackets currently issued, the program said. Television showed shiny black shoes that soldiers would wear on patrol instead of combat boots and said fur-lined coats would be provided in winter instead of the old wool ones now used. In a separate broadcast, television also reported that police would receive new uniforms with a less militaristic look. The new uniforms appeared to be another effort by the interim government to calm the restive armed forces, which launched a week of demonstrations earlier this month demanding a purge of officers linked to Ceausescu as well as the removal of the former defense minister, Nicolae Militaru. Protesting soldiers also complained of poor food and other supplies and a lowly image. In another response to the demands of young officers, Stanculescu announced that 20 generals who had been called out of retirement during the revolution had been removed from active duty, Romania Libera reported. The demonstrators had charged that the 74-year-old Militaru and other officers called out of retirement were part of the old order and were incapable of reforming the army. Stanculescu, named defense minister after Militaru's resignation Feb. 16, has promised to work with the military to remove Ceausescu loyalists. The television said that military authorities would seek the troops' suggestions on the new uniforms, then order them. It did not give a date or other details. In central Bucharest, meanwhile, about 50 people gathered around the base of a 15-foot-high statue of Lenin, which a few demonstrators covered with posters that said ``We're not robots,'' and ``Down with communism, down with its false symbols.'' A few police watched but did not interfere as the demonstrators denounced the government in heated conversations. There is widespread suspicion that interim President Ion Iliescu and other leading members of the caretaker government who were former ranking Communists still hold Marxist beliefs, despite the general consensus that communism is dead in Romania. One protester hurled a rock, which hit the statue's head with a loud, hollow clang. ``It is empty,'' said an onlooker.

DOC.HEAD: CIA Names First Female General Counsel
DOC.TEXT: Elizabeth Rindskopf, the principal deputy legal adviser to the State Department, will become the first female general counsel to the CIA in early April, the agency announced Sunday. Rindskopf, 46, who served as general counsel to the National Security Agency from June 1984 until September 1989, will succeed Russell J. Bruemmer. He is returning to private practice, the CIA said. Rindskopf graduated from the University of Michigan Law School in 1968. She worked as a civil rights lawyer in Atlanta and later directed the New Haven Legal Assistance and was deputy director of the Lawyer's Committee for Civil Rights Under Law. She also worked at the Federal Trade Commission, serving as litigation chief for the mergers division of the Bureau of Competition. She will be the eighth general counsel.

DOC.HEAD: Shamir Reported Unmoved by U.S. Pressure on Peace Process
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir is in no hurry to call a Cabinet vote on compromise proposals for starting Israeli-Palestinian talks despite reported U.S. pressure for a quick decision, an aide said Sunday. Israeli newspapers and state-run radio reported that U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III is pressing for answers this week on four key points holding up the peace process. But Shamir spokesman Avi Pazner said the prime minister has no plans to bring any compromise proposals to a vote at a scheduled meeting of the decision-making inner Cabinet on Wednesday. Asked about the pressure on Shamir, both from Baker and from Shamir's coalition partners in the center-left Labor Party, Pazner replied: ``He has overcome worse things.'' He denied Israeli news reports that Shamir already has agreed to a compromise on the makeup of the Palestinian delegation to an initial meeting that Baker wants held in Cairo, Egypt. He said Shamir would not consider compromise suggestions before a briefing by Foreign Minister Moshe Arens, who met Baker last week in Washington. Arens returned Sunday and was meeting Shamir in Tel Aviv. According to Israeli media reports, Baker is insisting that Israel accept as Palestinian negotiators at least one resident from Arab east Jerusalem and at least one who was deported by Israel from the occupied territories. Including a deportee reportedly is intended to meet PLO demands that outside Palestinians be represented, while at the same time satisfying Israel's insistence that it will talk only to residents of the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. The issue of east Jerusalem is complicated because Israel annexed the area into its capital after capturing it in the 1967 Middle East war. The PLO considers east Jerusalem the capital of its desired Palestinian state. Another reported point of Baker's plan is that Egypt would announce the Palestinian delegation; the PLO had demanded that it make the announcement. But Israeli newspapers said Baker is asking Israel to drop demands for iron-clad assurances that the PLO will not be involved in the peace process at some later point. Egypt and the PLO have reportedly agreed to these conditions, leaving the future of the peace contacts up to Israel. Two newspapers, Davar and Maariv, quoted an unidentified official in Washington as saying Baker's demands ``weren't an ultimatum, but not far from it.'' Davar, aligned with the Labor Party, said that unless Israel accepted Baker's four points, the United States may drop support for Israel's plan for Palestinian elections. Meanwhile, the Labor Party stepped up pressure on Shamir Sunday by refusing to approve two Cabinet appointees from the prime minister's Likud bloc unless Shamir also agrees to return Science Minister Ezer Weizman, a Labor member, to the inner Cabinet. Weizman was ousted in January over allegations that he had illegal contacts with PLO officials, but Israeli judicial officials have since said there is no evidence to prosecute him. Last week, Labor leaders threatened to quit the Likud-Labor coalition unless the Cabinet accepts compromises to start peace talks by March 7. Labor head Shimon Peres repeated the threat on Sunday. In the occupied lands, meanwhile, Palestinians staged a general strike to protest the alleged arson of a mosque last month in a West Bank village. The strike was called by the Moslem fundamentalist movement Hamas, or ``Zeal.'' A 20-year-old Palestinian from the Gaza Strip town of Rafah, Vahel Jamil El Hams, died at Israel's Tel Hashomer hospital after being shot in the back by troops, Arab reports said. The army confirmed the death and said it was checking the circumstances. His death raised to 659 the number of Palestinians killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians during the 26-month-old uprising in the occupied lands. Some 189 Palestinians have been killed by fellow Arabs on suspicion of collaborating with Israel, and 43 Israelis have also been slain.

DOC.HEAD: Democrat's `Horton Strategy' Backfires; He Apologizes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 9th graf, `At the ...,' to ADD that early-release program proposed by Martinez.
DOC.TEXT: A Democratic candidate for governor who borrowed the Republicans' Willie Horton strategy was forced to apologize after the tactic was denounced as racist and prejudicial to a defendant.
