Gubernatorial hopeful Rep. Bill Nelson kicked off his campaign Feb. 14 by promising to make a Florida case involving a black defendant into his rival's ``Willie Horton _ only worse.'' On Friday, he issued his apology. The six-term congressman is considered the front-runner among the three Democrats seeking a chance to challenge first-term Republican Gov. Bob Martinez. Martinez also has three Republican challengers. Horton, who had spent 10 years in prison in Massachusetts for murder, escaped during a furlough in 1987 and raped a Maryland woman and assaulted her fiance. A commercial during President Bush's 1988 campaign blamed Democrat Michael Dukakis for the tragedy and was credited as a major factor in the Massachusetts governor's defeat. The ad pictured Horton, a black man _ which critics said was a tactic to stir racial fears. When Nelson likened a Florida police slaying to the Horton case, the same charges arose. Nelson sought to blame Martinez for the case of Charles Street, who is accused of killing two Dade County police officers in 1988, 10 days after he was released from prison early because of overcrowding. The officers were killed after they went to subdue a man seen throwing rocks. Police said the officers' killer took a revolver away from one of them and fired at least seven shots, wounding them in the head and shoulders, above their bulletproof vests. Street had just finished serving eight years of a 15-year attempted-murder sentence for shooting a man outside a bar. He has a 20-page criminal record that includes numerous charges of assaulting police officers. At the time, corrections officials said Street served more time than average for a 15-year sentence because of frequent infractions in prison. But they also said he got out nearly two years earlier than he otherwise would have because of an early-release program proposed by Martinez in 1987 to help ease prison overcrowding. At a campaign kickoff held at the site of the slayings, Nelson predicted Martinez ``is going to have his hide nailed to the wall'' on the Street case. Martinez declined to respond to the charge, but others criticized Nelson's strategy. Former U.S. District Judge Alcee Hastings, the only black candidate in the race, stopped short of calling his fellow Democrat a racist but said he thought Nelson had hurt himself with black voters. ``I hope it will cause people to realize that you're seeing flapdoodle and stumblebum campaigns,'' said Hastings, who entered the race just three days after he was impeached and removed from the bench last year. ``I have no personal reason to believe he is a racist. It seems to me he was doing a ploy to get attention,'' Hastings said. In an unusual move, Circuit Judge Alfonso C. Sepe, who is presiding over Street's case, warned Nelson in a letter that making Street a cause celebre in the 1990 governor's race could prejudice the murder trial. ``My interest is in guaranteeing Mr. Street a fair trial,'' Sepe wrote. ``We are hoping to avoid the kind of pretrial publicity that would contaminate a jury required to try a presumably innocent man.'' Although Democrats howled loudly in 1988 that the Bush ad was racist and unethical, Nelson was defended by national Democratic Party chairman Ron Brown, who argued Democrats must learn to fight fire with fire. ``On balance, anybody that takes an objective look at dirty politics in this country, the Republicans are the champion,'' said Brown. Brown's GOP counterpart, Lee Atwater, considered a pioneer in modern negative campaigning, said he didn't know much about Nelson's statements and didn't want to comment. He said he was following the axiom ``Never interfere with your enemy while he is in the process of destroying himself.'' In his apology, Nelson said he would continue to question Florida's early-release program. But he added: ``The linkage of Charles Street to Willie Horton was a mistake, because of the racial implications. That is a mistake for which I apologize.'' ``In the heat of a campaign ... there are going to be mistakes and missteps,'' Nelson said. ``This campaign has heated up very early.'' The gubernatorial primary will be held Sept. 4.

DOC.HEAD: After Election Landslide, Sajudis to Seek Independence by Year's End
LaserPhoto NY17
DOC.TEXT: The leader of the Sajudis reform movement said Sunday that independence for Lithuania could be achieved this year after his group claimed a landslide victory in the Soviet Union's first multiparty election. In balloting for the Baltic republic's 141-seat parliament Saturday, voters appeared to have chosen the country's first legislature not dominated by Communists. The main contenders were the Sajudis Popular Front, which has led the drive for independence, and the reformed Lithuanian Communist Party. On the street outside the Sajudis headquarters, passers-by gathered excitedly around posters announcing the victory. Unofficial returns showed that of the 90 races decided, Sajudis-endorsed candidates took 72 seats and non-Sajudis candidates took 18, said Rita Dapkus, head of the Sajudis information agency. ``If that is not a landslide, then what is?'' Algimantas Cekuolis, a Sajudis officer, said at a news conference Sunday. ``It is a very clear indication of what the people of Lithuania think.'' Sajudis gathered the election results by calling local election commissions, and the tallies were believed to be reliable. Official results were not expected until Monday. Mrs. Dapkus said 45 races had no majority winner and will be decided by runoff votes on March 10, while six were invalidated by insufficient voter turnout or other factors. They will be decided in April. Turnout among the 2.56 million eligible voters was about 75 percent, officials said. Vytautus Landsbergis, Sajudis chairman, said the results showed Lithuanians trust his movement. ``We have a common and very clear goal. Our clear goal is statehood and the independence of Lithuania,'' he said. ``This goal is achievable this year.'' The new Parliament's chief task will be navigating the Baltic republic's difficult course to secession from the Soviet Union. Sajudis wants talks with Moscow to prepare for an orderly secession, which would break a 50-year-old tie that began with Lithuania's occupation by the Red Army in 1940 and its annexation later that year. The movement supports a neutral, sovereign Lithuania characterized by a market economy and guarantees for human and cultural rights. Although Sajudis dominated the voting, Landsbergis did not rule out a strong role for the reformed Communists in a coalition government selected by the new Parliament. He stressed the close ties between Sajudis and reform-minded Communist Party members. ``Probably we will not ignore the party as an administrative power and partner,'' said Landsbergis, who easily won election as a parliament deputy from northern Lithuania. But, he said, the hard-line Communists, who oppose independence, would probably not be welcome in the coalition. The participation by Sajudis and at least six other parties in parliamentary elections was a first in the Soviet Union. In December, Lithuania became the first of the 15 Soviet republics to legalize non-Communist parties. The reform Communists won 22 seats, but 13 of those were in districts where they were backed by Sajudis. Candidates from the Lithuanian chapter of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union, which remains loyal to Moscow and opposes full independence, won seven seats. Two non-party independents also won seats without Sajudis backing. The Communist winners included the party's first secretary, and Lithuanian President Algirdas Brazauskas, who in December defied Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev and led his party to split with moscow. Among the 72 Sajudis winners were 46 independents, 13 reform Communists, nine Social Democrats, two Greens and two Christian Democrats. Moldavians voted Sunday in their first free elections under Soviet rule and expressed hopes their new Parliament would be able to win greater sovereignty from Moscow. The main challenger to the Communists in Moldavia was the Moldavian Popular Front, which likes to compare itself to Sajudis. The Red Army occupied Lithuania in June 1940 in accordance with the secret terms of the Ribbentrop-Molotov pact, in which Nazi Germany and the Soviet Union divided central Europe between themselves. Lithuania's old Parliament was coerced into voting to join the Soviet Union the next month, and Lithuania was formally annexed by the Soviets on Aug. 24, 1940. Lithuania had emerged as an independent state in 1918 with the collapse of the Russian empire in World War I.

DOC.HEAD: Five Family Members Dead, Two Injured in Fire
DOC.TEXT: Fire swept through a home early Sunday, killing five family members, including two children, authorities said. An 8-year-old boy and an adult suffered burns on the hands and arms and were listed in fair condition at a hospital. A space heater was being used to ward off near-freezing temperatures when the fire broke out at the wood-frame home, but the cause of the blaze in this northeastern Florida town of 1,000 was not immediately known, said sheriff's Capt. Richard Schauland. Killed were three adults and two youngsters, ages 4 and 7, he said. Barry Joseph Carter, 30, was awakened by son Barry Jr.'s screams and carried the 8-year-old to safety, but was driven back by heat and smoke when he tried to re-enter, said Deputy Tim Rollins. The boy and another adult were hospitalized. The precise relationship between the victims was not known in some cases, authorities said.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Urges Black Unity At Massive Rally In Natal Province
LaserPhoto DUR1
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 6 grafs at end of story to UPDATE with bodies of youths found, Mandela speaks at second rally. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela, seeking to end four years of fighting among black factions in Natal Province, appealed to the warring groups Sunday to put down their weapons and fight together for racial equality. Mandela, released Feb. 11 after 27 years in prison, still supports the low-level armed struggle waged by his African National Congress guerrilla movement. But he said the black-on-black fighting in the southeastern province hindered the battle against apartheid, South Africa's policy of racial segregation. ``Even now as we stand together on the threshold of a new South Africa, Natal is in flames,'' Mandela told an estimated 100,000 people who filled three adjacent soccer fields. ``My message to those of you involved in this battle of brother against brother is this: take your guns, your knives and your pangas and throw them into the sea,'' Mandela said. Pangas are similar to machetes. Mandela and his wife, Winnie, arrived by helicopter to rousing cheers. He spoke from a 4-story-tall platform draped with huge flags of the ANC and its ally, the South African Communist Party. Many in the mostly black crowd waved the green, black and gold banner of the African National Congress and chanted ``ANC! ANC!'' About 3,000 blacks, mostly Zulus, have died since 1986 in the power struggle in Natal. The main combatants are the ANC-aligned United Democratic Front and Inkatha, a relatively conservative Zulu political group headed by Mangosuthu Buthelezi. Buthelezi is a staunch oppenent of apartheid, but he differs with the ANC over the best way to fight it. The ANC favors sanctions, boycotts, strikes and guerrilla attacks to put pressure on the government. Buthelezi does not endorse any of these actions and is a proponent of capitalism in contrast to the socialist-oriented ANC. While the most intense battles have been in the townships around Durban and Pietermaritzburg, 50 miles inland, the fighting has spread throughout Natal. Several of Mandela's ANC colleagues, including Walter Sisulu, have been in Natal since Thursday meeting with leaders of the Front, Inkatha and local clergymen. Mandela made several conciliatory remarks concerning Inkatha and Buthelezi, whom he praised for demanding the ANC be legalized and political prisoners be released. President F.W. de Klerk on Feb. 2 legalized the ANC, which had been banned since 1960. Mandela also praised the Zulu leader for refusing to negotiate with the white-led government while other black groups were outlawed and their leaders imprisoned. ``This stand of Inkatha has contributed in no small measure to making it difficult for the (white) regime to implement successive schemes designed to perpetuate minority rule,'' Mandela said. Inkatha leaders took the unusual step of urging their supporters to attend the rally to hear Mandela. Inkatha has long staged its own rallies, separate from those in support of the Front and the ANC. On numerous occasions, violence has broken out when the crowd from one rally headed home through neighborhoods dominated by the other. About 3,000 marshals were on hand to prevent violence at the rally, which lasted several hours. As Mandela spoke, police reported that the bodies of six black youths were found at an abandoned church in Empangeni, 90 miles north of Durban. Police said they were still investigating the attack, which apparently took place Saturday. Later Sunday, Mandela spoke to tens of thousands of blacks in the central city of Bloemfontein, where he called on de Klerk to dismiss Defense Minister Magnus Malan and suspend Law and Order Minister Adriaan Vlok. Both men have come under heavy criticism following accusations that the security forces have been involved in the killings of dozens of anti-apartheid activists in the past decade. A judicial commission appointed by de Klerk is investigating the charges. Mandela said the South African government had ``systematically undermined'' the rule of law with such measures as the 3{-year-old state of emergency. ``We note with appreciation that there are certain areas where policemen are acting with restraint and fulfilling the role of protecting all our people,'' Mandela said. ``But we view with horror the moral decay within certain sections of the security establishment.''

DOC.HEAD: Moldavians Hope for Greater Sovereignty After Sunday Vote
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Results not expected until Monday.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Lithuania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Moldavians voted Sunday in their first free elections under Soviet rule and expressed hopes their new Parliament would be able to win greater sovereignty from Moscow. Many voters who gathered in parks after casting their ballots seemed excited by the prospect of a new government and the ability to choose candidates. ``We are learning democracy and we want to use the Parliament as a peaceful way to gain our sovereignty,'' said Anatoly Zhdanov, who said he was Moldavian by nationality despite his Russian name. Zhdanov, a 26-year-old employee in a brick factory, said he voted for the Moldavian Popular Front, an independent political movement that was the main challenger to the ruling Communist Party in the contest for the 380 seats in the Moldavian Parliament. ``Of course we are going to win and then our demands will be met,'' Klavdia Zhaloba said, smiling as she sold copies of Glasul, an independent Moldavian newspaper. With more than 200 candidates on the ballot, the Popular Front hoped to get at least 50 percent of the seats in Parliament. ``We think part of the other deputies will come around to our side,'' said Yuri Roshka, a Popular Front leader and candidate. The Moldavian Popular Front likes to compare itself to Sajudis, the Lithuanian reform group which on Sunday claimed victory in parliamentary elections. It campaigned on a platform that favors secession from the Soviet Union. ``We want to be an independent republic _ not with the Russians, and not with the Romanians. And above all we want our sovereignty,'' Anatoly Goncharov said as he listened to news of election returns in Lithuania on his radio in a park. While Lithuania enjoyed two decades of independence between the World Wars, Moldavia, a republic of 4 million people in the southwest corner of the Soviet Union, has not known independence this century. Until the czarist empire fell apart in 1917, Moldavia was the Russian province of Bessarabia and after World War I it was ceded to Romania, with which it shares a nearly identical language and many historical and cultural heroes. Moldavia's common heritage with Romania was suppressed when Stalin annexed it to the Soviet Union in 1940. But a half-century of Soviet domination failed to diminish the desire of many of the estimated 3 million ethnic Moldavians to reunite with their neighbor. Demands for unity surged in Moldavia when Romania's December revolution toppled Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. Sympathy for Romania is visible in the center of Kishinev, where a Romanian flag is pasted on a statue of the Romanian King Stephan the Great. Some residents wear Romanian flags pinned on their lapels. But the Popular Front says reunification should be put on hold for the moment in favor of rebuilding the republic's economy and restoring Moldavian culture, stunted by decades of Russification. ``We want to unite with Romania, but it is not possible yet. First, we have to create a democratic system here, and I think reunification should happen when there is a declaration of the will of the people,'' Roshka said. The Popular Front said it would press for the right to engage in direct economic relations with other countries, a multiparty political system, private property and a market economy. Those kind of changes will take time, especially if the Popular Front is unable to muster the two-thirds' vote in Parliament that is required to amend the constitution. Even a new government may be unable to solve all the problems facing Moldavia. Representatives of other ethnic groups accuse the Popular Front of whipping up ethnic sentiments that may make dialogue difficult in the future. ``The Russian-speaking population is very frightened,'' said Vladimir Solonar, a leader of the Unity movement formed to protect the rights of Russians, Ukrainians and Jews, many of whose families have lived in Moldavia for generations. The movement fielded candidates for each of the 65 districts in Kishinev. Parliamentary elections were also held Sunday in the Central Asian republic of Tadzhikistan, recently rocked by ethnic unrest in which at least 22 people died. Reports from the capital of Dushanbe, monitored in London, said voting was orderly. Official radio put the voter turnout at 64 percent and attributed the low turnout to the 6 p.m. curfew that has been in effect since Feb. 12 to prevent more unrest. A parliamentary vote also took place Sunday in neighboring Kirghizia, a mountainous republic on the border with China. The official Tass news agency said official results in both elections were expected to be announced March 1.

DOC.HEAD: Bush and Kohl Extol Virtues of German Unification
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 30th graf to add Sharon quotes, picks up 31st graf pvs, Bush and Kohl x x x
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Sunday he and Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany agreed in weekend talks that a unified Germany would continue as ``a full member of NATO,'' including military participation in the Western alliance. Kohl said ``neutralism would be a very false solution.'' After two days of discussions regarding delicate issues of a unified Germany, Kohl said he recognizes ``the legitimate security interests of all states'' in Europe, particularly Poland. ``Nobody needs to be afraid,'' the West German leader said. Bush chimed in that if he were alarmed about the prospect of a single Germany, he would not be endorsing reunification _ as he had several times previously. There have been fears in Poland _ decimated by the Nazis in World War II _ that a new Germany would seek to regain border territory that was formerly under German rule. Nonetheless, Bush and Kohl both said they saw no need to add Poland to the group of four nations that will dicuss reunification with the two German states. Poland, like East Germany, has abandoned its Communist monopoly government. Bush pointedly said that the United States regards the current European borders, including Germany's long border with Poland, as inviolable. And Kohl said the border question ``will be settled definitely by a free elected all-German government.'' He said ``nobody has any intention of linking the question of national unity with changes in existing borders.'' East Germany is a member of the Soviet-dominated Warsaw Pact, and many in Europe have supported the concept of a neutral Germany rather than one allied with the United States and its NATO allies. East Germany is abandoning its communist government and the Germanys are pursuing a common currency based on the West German system. ``Neutralism would be a very false solution for us,'' said Kohl, adding that he did not expect that the German people would support a move away from NATO. He said the West Germans had proven their reliability by accepting missiles during the 1980s. ``The security link between North American and Europe is ... for a united Germany, of vital importance,'' said Kohl. He reiterated his support for the continuing presence of U.S. military forces in Germany. Kohl said he understands the delicacy of the German reunification issue in several European countries, but said, ``nobody needs to be afraid'' of that. Kohl was asked whether Soviet troops _ long based in East Germany _ might be welcomed to stay in a new Germany. ``A unified Germany cannot belong to two different security systems,'' he said. He was asked if Germany might develop an independent nuclear weapons system, and replied, ``We are not at all longing to be an atomic power.'' One other foreign policy issue surfaced _ the elections in Nicaragua. Bush said ``whoever wins ... will find a better climate'' with the United States, so long as the balloting was certified as free and fair and the resulting government maintains a democratic system. The various questions of German reunification are at the center of the dramatic political upheavals that have engulfed Europe over the past year. Bush and Kohl talked about delicate issues that are heightened by concerns involving German aggression in two world wars. The allies which defeated Germany in World War II _ The United States, Soviet Union, Great Britain and France _ have agreed to convene meetings that are likely to lead to a unified Germany, perhaps as soon as this year. Bush said the timetable was up to the Germans. He said he was neither trying to ``speed it up'' or ``slow it down.'' `If events are moving faster than we expected, it just means our common goal'' of a unified Germany, will be achieved sooner than expected, he said. Unification talks between East and West Germany are to begin after East German elections March 18. Following two days of talks at Camp David, Bush and Kohl drove down from the presidential retreat to meet with reporters at a facility in Camp Greentop _ also in the Catoctin Mountain Park. Bush and Kohl took turns answering questions. Bush called their talks ``extraordinarily frank.'' The two men alternated taking questions on a stage in a camping recreation hall. Given sweeping changes in the Soviet Union and the Soviet bloc, Bush was asked to describe the enemy which necessitates military forces in Europe. ``The enemy is unpreditability,'' said Bush. ``The enemy is instability. And it is for that reason that there are agreed security provisions. Who out here was smart enough ... to predict the changes that have taken place over the past year?'' He added, ``What we want to do in a period of exciting change is to have a stable western Europe. Eastern European countries are throwing off the yoke of communism. The policy of NATO has prevailed ... but nobody can predict for fact certain what will come and so what we want to do is use our good offices and our alignment with NATO to help with stability.'' Bush acknowledged that ``some are saying we ought to take all the troops out,'' commenting, ``in my judgment that would not provide for a stable Europe ... The enemy is instability and unpredictability as this rapid change continues to unfold inside the Soviet Union and inside Eastern Europe.'' Bush and Kohl said they discussed difficult issues engendered by prospects of reunification of West and East Germany. One was whether the new Germany would maintain its ties to NATO and another involved border areas of Poland which were part of pre-war Germany. ``We do recognize the legitimate security interests of all states,'' Kohl said in his opening statement, noting he was speaking specifically of Poland. There have been concerns that a unified Germany would seek to regain control of some border areas and Poland has asked to be included in unification talks. Bush said the United States supports treaties which reaffirm the current Poland-German borders but he agreed with Kohl that there was no need to add Poland to the four-plus-two group that will meet to discuss unification. The two Germanys are to begin unification talks after the March 18 elections in East Germany.Then they will discuss external security issues with the four powers which defeated Nazi Germany in World War II. Bush said, ``It's not for the United States to set a timetable. It's not for us to say how fast'' unification would occur. Others have raised concerns about reunification, including Ariel Sharon, Israel's former defense minister and a member of the Israeli parliament. Asked on CBS's ``Face the Nation'' if he was worried about reunification, he replied: ``Yes, of course. We, the Jews _ we that suffered six million casualties dead by the Germans _ we must be aware of that. ... I think the free world, including West Germany, should take all the necessary steps that such unification will not harm anymore _ not the free world and not the Jews,'' he said. Bush and Kohl were joined by close advisers, and the American side said the two German states should begin soon to consult with the four powers as they make progress in their reunification talks in parallel consultations before the formal two-plus-four talks begin. Both men said there was no need for an extra NATO summit, noting upcoming economic and NATO meetings.

DOC.HEAD: Iranian Official: Iran Opposes Hostage-taking
DOC.TEXT: A top Iranian official said in an interview published Sunday that his country opposes hostage taking, and another report said groups holding foreigners in Lebanon might let them go without the need for diplomatic pressure. In an interview with the English-language Tehran Times, Iranian Chief Justice and cleric Ayatollah Mohammad Yazdi said: ``Iran opposes taking hostages, terrorism, and air piracy because these are contrary to Islamic and humanitarian principles.'' In the interview, sent to The Associated Press by telefax, Yazdi also said Iran recognizes international law and staunchly opposes any interference in the international affairs of other nations. Yazdi's statements came amid other indications that the Iranian government is distancing itself from pro-Iranian groups in Lebanon that are believed to hold the 18 Westerners. They include eight Americans, four Britons, an Italian, an Irishman, two West Germans and two Swiss. The longest held is 42-year-old Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associted Press when kidnapped in March 1985. The Persian daily Ettela'at, which has the second-largest circulation in Iran, said in an editorial Sunday that the groups holding the foreigners might free them. The official Islamic Republic News Agency quoted the paper as saying: ``The Lebanese Moslem people who have been holding the Western hostages since their captivity may choose to free them at their discretion without the need for diplomatic give and take.'' The paper claimed that Americans and other Westerners do not really want to see the hostages freed because they have become a means of trying to discredit Iran's 1979 Islamic Revolution, according to the news agency account monitored in Nicosia. The Ettela'at editorial echoed a similar statement in the Tehran Times on Thursday that said the hostages should be released without preconditions on Islamic and humanitarian grounds. It was the first such known statement by an Iranian newspaper. On Friday, Sheik Mohammed Hussein Fadlallah, Lebanon's most influential Shiite Moslem cleric, said the hostages were being used by the West to distort the image of Islam and a means should be found to free them. While many Iranian officials have said in the past that the Islamic Republic opposed hostage taking, Iran had set preconditions for using its influence to try to get the hostages freed. President Hashemi Rafsanjani said last year that the United States should release Iranian assets frozen since the revolution if it wanted Tehran's help with the hostages. Their freedom is believed linked to factional fighting within the Iranian government. There were signs this week that the power struggle is deepening between the pragmatists seeking a more open Iran and the radicals, who believe that contacts with the West will dilute the Islamic revolution. The main Iranian oppostion group, The Mujahedeen Khalq, has said in statements from its Baghdad headquarters this week that anti-government riots have broken out in a number of Iranian cities. The reports could not be independently confirmed, although the official news agency reported 30 arrests at a demonstration after cancellation of a soccer match.

DOC.HEAD: Winter Weather In The Northeast
DOC.TEXT: Snow was scattered over the Northeast on Sunday, accompanied by cold air, and blizzard warnings were issued for parts of Alaska. At midday, snow fell from western Maine across New York state, and over eastern Ohio, West Virginia, much of Pennsylvania and northern New Jersey. Snowfall during the 6 hours ending at noon included 4 inches at Chicopoee Falls, Mass.; and 3 inches at Bridgeport and Hartford, Conn., Providence, R.I., and South Weymouth, Mass. Warnings of gale force wind were posted along the Atlantic Coast from Maine through Virginia. Low temperatures combined with the strong wind to produce very cold wind chill factors. Boston, Philadelphia and New York City were only in the mid to low 20s Sunday, two days after highs in the mid 60s. Blizzard warnings were posted in Alaska over the northern Seward Peninsula, lower Kobuk Valley, and the Arctic Coast west of Barrow. A winter storm watch was posted over the Arctic Coast at Barrow and eastward. Temperatures were expected to remain 15 below zero to 25 degrees below zero with wind chills of near 80 below zero. Elsewhere, snow was scattered over western Iowa and northwestern Missouri. Duluth, Minn., posted a record low of 26 degrees below zero. Sunday's low for the Lower 48 states was 27 below zero at Hibbing, Minn. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EST ranged from 5 degrees above zero at both Houlton, Maine, and Sault Ste. Marie, Mich., to 78 at McAllen, Texas.

DOC.HEAD: Premier To Run for Communists, Giving Party Last Chance for Survival
With AM-Germany-Campaign, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: East German Premier Hans Modrow agreed Sunday to lead his party in March 18 elections, giving the embattled Communists a last chance at political survival. According to recent opinion polls, Modrow remains the most popular politician in East Germany, despitehis affiliation with a party that has been disgraced and stripped of most of its former authority. The leftist Social Democratic Party is expected to poll a majority of votes in East Germany's first-ever free elections, followed by the more conservative Christian Democrats. But Modrow's decision to stay with his party could boost the Communists' chances of retaining at least a minor role in the next leadership. Modrow told the 530 delegates at an East Berlin convention of his Party for Democratic Socialism that he would lead it in the March vote although it ``wasn't easy'' to make up his mind, the official ADN news agency said. The 62-year-old politician had been waffling over the leadership issue for several days. He is apparently reluctant to become a scapegoat for four decades of Communist economic mismanagement, which the Bonn government claims has brought East Germany to the brink of ruin. But Modrow, a member of the ruling Politburo from 1958 until the Communist Party disbanded that body and changed its name last December, enjoys widespread support as a reformer and is the party's most likely vote-getter. ``For all the things I tried to do for a policy of reform in 1989 and maybe even earlier, I now know very well that it wasn't enough,'' ADN quoted Modrow as saying. All leading East German parties have ruled out building coalition governments with the Communists. Ibrahim Boehme, leader of the Social Democrats, said Modrow was ``a good candidate, but unfortunately for the wrong party.'' Modrow has been premier since November, when a new Cabinet was seated following the ouster of hard-line Erich Honecker and his top lieutenants, most of whom are now under investigation for alleged corruption and misuse of office. Polls have predicted Boehme's party will emerge with the biggest bloc of votes in the elections, but it is unclear whether the Social Democrats will be able to build a government on their own. West German officials have speculated the vote may be so divided the new 400-member parliament could abandon efforts to build a Cabinet and instead vote for immediate merger with West Germany. If a new government is formed, it is expected to open talks with Bonn immediately on how to bail out the economy. Meanwhile, ADN reported the East German chief prosecutor's office was investigating Honecker for allegedly directing $45.5 million in government funds to a hard currency bank account to which only he had access. The currency was allegedly money that West Germany paid for the release of East German political prisoners, ADN said. Also on Sunday, West Germany's Der Spiegel magazine reported Honecker claimed he was personally responsible for preventing a bloody crackdown on demonstrators in the early stages of East Germany's peaceful revolution. Honecker said in a letter to prosecutors that he ordered police and soldiers in the city of Leipzig not to fire during a demonstration Oct. 9, according to Der Spiegel. Der Spiegel distributed its report to Western news agencies in advance of its arrival on newsstands Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Campesinos Line Up To Vote Against Sandinistas
With AM-Nicaragua, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Eduardo Guerrero rose just before midnight, saddled and mounted his dappled gray horse and rode four hours through the dark hills before dawn Sunday to vote for the first time in his life. The 24-year-old peasant-rancher stood in line with about 2,000 other campesinos anxious to have their say about 10{ years of revolutionary leftist Sandinista government. Jose Mejia, president of the polling station, said he expected well over 90 percent of the 2,300 voters registered in Los Chinamos to cast ballots. The hamlet of thatch-roofed, bamboo-sided houses along a rocky road lined with banana trees is in the heart of the opposition stronghold of Chontales province. Nearly all the men wore straw cowboy hats, jeans and Texas-style boots, many with spurs. More than 100 horses were tethered along a fence behind the wooden, tin-roofed polling station resembling an ample shed. All of those consulted were adamantly anti-Sandinista. Several said the incumbents would be lucky to get a few votes in Los Chinamos, perhaps from some, but not all, of the score of unarmed soldiers in camouflage uniforms interspersed in groups of four or five among the peasants. Pregnant women, those with infants in tow and the elderly and infirm were given priority when the polling station opened at 7 a.m. Guerrero had arrived just after 4 a.m. when there were already about 200 people lined up to vote. ``It's well worth it to lose a day. We don't like the Sandinistas much around here,'' he said. Many of those interviewed expressed open admiration and support for the U.S.-supported Contra rebels camped in the hills around Los Chinamos and throughout northern Chontales. The rebels had clashed Saturday with Sandinista soldiers stationed down the road. A Sandinista officer said one soldier was killed and another wounded. He said security for the voting was increased after intelligence reports showed the Contras planned to put in an appearance in Chinamos during the voting. Judging from the comments of those standing in line, the counterrevolutionaries most likely would have been cheered. ``When the Sandinistas won the war against Somoza, just about everyone in Nicaragua was Sandinista,'' said Jose Alvarez Perez, 26. ``But we've been negatively affected by them.'' The men complained bitterly of what they said was harsh repression of relatives and neighbors suspected of collaboration with the rebels. Prospero Alvarez said he was jailed three times in recent years for a total of four months. ``They put us in jail for nothing,'' he said. It was unclear if his open sympathy for the rebels pre-dated his incarceration or was a byproduct of it. Humberto Salazar, 52, said his son Antonio was killed by Sandinista forces last year as he returned home from a corn patch. ``They just opened fire. Didn't even yell out to him,'' he said. ``We don't believe in the promises of Daniel Ortega,'' Alvarez said of the regime's campaign vow that ``everything will be better.'' The government contends that once its re-election is certified as free and fair, Washington will have no choice but to end support for the Contras. Ortega says a definite end to the war will result in progress towards prosperity. But those around Los Chinamos doubt the war will end as long as the Sandinistas remain in power. ``The Contra is fighting against a system that does not allow him to live,'' said another peasant rancher, who asked not to be identified. ``As long as the Sandinista regime continues, the war continues. When they leave, the war will end.'' ``Those of us who have suffered the war personally do not believe it will end,'' said a 32-year-old woman, who also declined to provide her name. ``My husband has been fighting (for the Contras) for six years. The Sandinistas had taken him away once and he wasn't going to wait for them to take him again. I'm left with seven children to take care of,'' she added.

DOC.HEAD: Cisneros Endorses Richards, Down Plays Alleged Slur
DOC.TEXT: Former San Antonio Mayor Henry Cisneros has endorsed Democratic gubernatorial candidate Ann Richards despite allegations that she used the term ``wetbacks'' in a 1976 campaign speech. Cisneros said he had been unaware of the controversy until Saturday, when he went ahead with scheduled endorsement anyway. The Hispanic-oriented newspaper Tiempo ran an article Feb. 22 alleging that Ms. Richards referred to illegal aliens as ``wetbacks'' while running for Travis County commissioner. She responded by accusing Jim Mattox, a rival for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination, of planting the story as part of a smear campaign. The Mattox campaign said Ms. Richards is just trying to shift the blame. But Cisneros praised Ms. Richards for her longtime support of Hispanics and called the allegation of a racial slur ``the last gasps of a campaign that has nothing else to talk about.'' ``Not anyone who is a serious student of Ann's record can take it seriously,'' said Cisneros, one of the country's best known Hispanics in politics. ``It just isn't in character, and I think it's inconsequential in the final analysis.'' Ernesto Fraga, publisher of Waco-based Tiempo, produced handwritten copies of a speech Ms. Richards made to a labor group during her successful 1976 campaign for county commissioner. He said the Mattox campaign had nothing to do with the article. A sentence in the speech text Fraga quoted said: ``If it takes a man to hire non-union labor, cross picket lines and work wetbacks then I say thank god for a woman or anyone else who is willing to take over.'' Ms. Richards originally said the part of the speech that uses the term wasn't in her handwriting. She later said she may have written ``wetbacks,'' but maintained she didn't say it. Ms. Richards stressed the minority hiring and promotion record of the state treasury, which she heads, saying it is the best of any state agency. She also promised that Hispanics would play a key role in her administration if she were elected.

DOC.HEAD: Bright and Brief
DOC.TEXT: To hear some people tell it, there is money to burn in this trendy seaside community, but it still isn't every day that a bank tosses $42,500 into the trash. ``We're sort of embarrassed,'' Great American Bank spokesman Brian Luscomb said Friday, a day after the windfall was recovered from a municipal trash truck that had hauled it away. ``It was an accident and we're really not commenting much beyond that,'' said Luscomb, who added that a bank employee whose name wasn't released put the money in the wrong container. When the garbage truck got to the dump, officials there had been warned about the missing cash, and they had the driver take his load to a city yard instead. The garbage was dumped there and municipal employees dug through the trash until they found the cash. The city's trash collectors must try to track down the owners of expensive items but can keep lesser ones, said General Services Director David Niederhaus.

Just call Amtrak No. 581 the little train that could if you gave it long enough. A San Diego-Los Angeles commuter run that normally takes two hours and 45 minutes took more than twice that Friday. The first locomotive broke down, the second was sluggish, the crew walked off the job and the replacement crew members couldn't get their van to start. ``It seems that everything that could have gone wrong did,'' said Renee Banks, an Amtrak spokeswoman in Washington. ``This certainly is an unfortunate incident. It really doesn't happen that often.'' First, the locomotive's air compressor failed, stalling the train's engines and leaving the roughly 500 passengers without air conditioning on a day when temperatures reached the high 70s. The train sat on the tracks south of Oceanside for almost 90 minutes until an engine borrowed from Santa Fe Railway was hitched to the cars. But the replacement engine, designed to haul freight trains, was far slower, and progress was painstaking. Then, with the train just 11 miles from its destination, the Amtrak crew stopped work _ and with it the train _ citing a federal law that doesn't allow railway crews to work past the end of their shifts. The train sat for yet another hour as a replacement crew struggled with a van that wouldn't start. The crew members finally borrowed an Amtrak superintendent's car and drove to the train. Eventually, No. 581 did arrive in Los Angeles, about six hours after it left San Diego _ enough time to make a round-trip journey between the two cities.

DOC.HEAD: Renewed Fighting Thwarts Efforts To Reopen Road
DOC.TEXT: Rival Christian forces battled with mortars and machine guns in east Beirut Sunday, blocking efforts to reopen a key road junction linking their districts. A police spokesman said the three-hour battle began when a mediation committee tried to remove mines and barricades blocking a traffic circle linking a district controlled by Samir Geagea's Lebanese Forces militia with territory dominated by Gen. Michel Aoun's troops. The intersection links the militia-controlled pockets of Nabaa and Ashrafiyeh with the army-held neighborhood of Sin el-Fil and Horsh Tabet. The police spokesman, who cannot be named in line with regulations, said the clash intensified into an exchange of mortar rounds between the warring factions across the whole of east Beirut. Geagea's militia blamed the escalation on Aoun's troops, saying they opened fire at soldiers preparing to remove mines from the sand barricades. ``Aoun wants to block efforts aimed at stabilizing the cease-fire,'' a communique said. Aoun's command countered that the militiamen were ``cheating the population by claiming they want to reopen roads.'' Police said the exchange started several fires in the miltia-held district of Ashrafiyeh and the army-controlled district of Furn el-Shubbak before the fighting subsided into an intermittent exchange of sniper fire at dusk. The rival forces also clashed across roads reopened earlier in the day for the first time in three weeks. The police spokesman said two mortar rounds crashed into a Moslem district of west Beirut early in the evening, but no casualties were reported. The two sides fought despite separate efforts by a Christian mediation committee and a Palestinian delegation to end the bloodletting. Despite a cease-fire that went into effect on Feb. 17, there was little sign of an end to the 26-day battle for control of the 310-square-mile Christian enclave. Geagea's headquarters reported one of their fighters was killed by sniper fire and Aoun's command said two soldiers were wounded. By police count, at least 691 people have been killed and 1,915 wounded in the fighting that began Jan. 30, the worst between Christian rivals since the civil war between Moslems and Christians broke out in April 1975. Parts of the city have been left in ruins and Aoun's troops have corralled thousands of Geagea's militiamen in several districts of east Beirut in the power struggle. The roads crossing the confrontation lines were reopened after several days of negotiating between the rival forces by a mediation committee of three independent Christian leaders. Some of the roads had been mined and others remain so, posing dangers to civilians fleeing to safer areas or trying to repair their shattered homes. A committee statement said the mediators will continue their efforts ``until all roads are reopened and the combatants disengaged.'' Geagea, whose forces control the Christian sector's ports and two-thirds of the enclave, has indicated he is prepared to negotiate. But Aoun, who started the fighting by moving against Geagea, showed no sign of seeking a negotiated settlement. ``I'm convinced that the committee will not be able to achieve any result because Geagea's declared stands contradict his statements,'' he was quoted as saying by the London-based Al-Hayat newspaper. Geagea has rejected Aoun's demand that the militia's 6,000 hardcore fighters, who have been backed by thousands of reservists, be disbanded and absorbed into his 19,000-strong army and the Lebanese Forces transformed into a purely political organization. The Christian warlord instead proposes a joint command for his militia and Aoun's troops. President Elias Hrawi, elected by Parliament in November with a mandate to carry out a Lebanese peace plan, has dismissed Aoun as military commander. However, Aoun does not recognize Hrawi's authority. Aoun also opposes a Syrian-backed peace plan, saying it should call for a complete withdrawal of Syrian troops from Lebanon. The 40,000 Syrian soldiers came under a 1976 Arab League peacekeeping mandate, but Aoun says they are really acting as a Moslem ally in the country's civil war.

DOC.HEAD: Voting In Countryside Peaceful, Seven Precincts Closed
With AM-Nicaragua Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Voting in the Nicaraguan countryside was largely peaceful Sunday, but authorities said at least seven polling places didn't open because of Contra guerrilla activity. ``The electoral process in the main is going normally, although there is some counterrevolutionary activity,'' said Interior Minister Tomas Borge. Four polling places did not open near Santa Rosa del Penon, about 50 miles north of Managua. Two in the central province of Matagalpa did not open, nor did one in the Atlantic Coast province of Zelaya, Borge said. There are 4,394 polling places nationwide. All three areas are known for heavy Contra rebel activity, and all are strongholds of opposition to the leftist Sandinista government. The most serious incident took place Saturday night near the town of La Cruz del Rio Grande, about 65 miles north of the Atlantic Coast town of Bluefields, when two Sandinista party activists were kidnapped, authorities said. ``When we heard about the kidnappings we got together and decided the safest thing to do would be to close the precinct,'' said Dr. Cirilo Omier, president of the regional vote collection center in Bluefields, in a telephone interview. He said representatives of the Sandinista party and the United National Opposition coalition agreed to the closures, as did the Indian organization Yatama, which supports UNO's presidential candidate but is running its own races locally, and the small Central American Unionist Party. President Daniel Ortega, seeking re-election to a six -year term, said Saturday night that Contra activity had been reported north of Santa Rosa in the province of Leon. Contra fighters also reportedly were seen along major roads in the central province of Chontales, also a Contra and opposition stronghold. However, two Associated Press reporters in Chontales saw the voting to be quiet and peaceful throughout the region. More than 800 people were waiting in line in the morning at two voting stations in La Gateada, a hamlet about 120 miles east of Managua. Three hundred unarmed soldiers lined up in the nearby hamlet of Muha, near a military base established to fight the Contras. In nearby Villa Sandino, dozens of peasants came down from their remote mountain homes on horses and mules to vote at five stations in town, where about 900 people were in line as of mid-morning. An army spokesman said security had been beefed up in the area because squads of Contras had been seen, but no incidents were reported. Voting was also smooth in Jalapa, 130 miles to the north of Managua near the Honduran border. Troops patrolled the area, only 20 miles from Contra base camps at Yamales in Honduras, but no incidents were reported. ``Monday we're going to have chicken soup,'' with opposition candidate Violeta Barrios de Chamorro as the chicken, said Marvin Idiarquerz, a 22-year-old Sandinista supporter in Jalapa.

DOC.HEAD: Schools Use February To Focus on Black History
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 2nd graf, `Sameena Parveen,...' to clarify identity of John Henry. Also moved in advance Feb. 22 as b0393.
DOC.TEXT: Eight-year-old Erik Hundley of South Nyack, N.Y., rattles off the civil rights struggles of Martin Luther King Jr. after a week of study but admits, ``I forgot who Harriet Tubman was.'' Sameena Parveen, 13, an eighth grader at Kettering Middle School in Largo, Md., is intrigued with the underground railroad movement and the role of a virtual unknown, John Henry, who mapped the secret routes. And, 12-year-old LaKeisha Lewis of Spencer, Okla., becomes ``sort of angry'' when she thinks about ``how the civil rights thing came about ... because I don't think people should be treated like that.'' The study of black American heroes and heroines went into high gear in schools this month, as it does every February, in recognition of Black History Month. Although started in 1926 by Carter G. Woodson in recognition of the birthdays of Abraham Lincoln and Frederick Douglass, celebration of the special month gained momentum when King's birthday became a national holiday. Now, King's January birthday is used as the springboard into February's recognition of other black leaders during special school assemblies, field trips, classroom projects, book reports, skits and plays. ``It's good there's a month to remember the accomplishments of the blacks,'' said Sameena, a native of India. ``Some students don't seem to care, and some people do change their attitudes (toward other races). I think most of the students only act like they really care and then quickly forget.'' Bernadine Lyles of the Los Angeles Unified School District, the nation's second largest after New York, said many of the 646 schools start with the King holiday to go into their program on black Americans. ``That holiday has created much more awareness,'' said Ms. Lyles, instructional adviser of the elementary level for the multicultural unit of the Office of Instruction. ``Most students have some idea of the Civil Rights movement and its effect on African American history and culture.'' San Francisco schools spokeswoman Madelaine Eaton said all 64,000 students participate in a Martin Luther King essay contest as part of Black History Month. The district, which is 20 percent black, also offers students and teachers an array of black American art and language resources but each school is left to develop its own particular programs. In some other states, the teaching of black history is determined mainly by the size of the black student body and by the interests of the teachers. At Community High School in Carbondale, Ill., English teacher Anna Jackson said there are no special assemblies for either King's birthday or Black History Month. ``I really try to integrate black history throughout the year'' by incorporating the works of blacks and other minorities in the classroom assignments, said Ms. Jackson, one of six minority teachers. About 30 percent of the 1,000 students at the school are black or Asian. To her dismay, though, the school usually gives semester exams during the days leading up to King's birthday ``so the kids are focusing on preparing for the exam.'' At the private all-girl La Reine High School in the Washington, D.C., suburb of Suitland, Md., Sister Kateri said it is a frustrating struggle to keep up with the changing needs of the 475 young women. The student body was 12 percent black in 1973 and is now 63 percent black. Three of the 42 faculty members are black. ``I would say that (the study of black history) has come slowly but we have tried to integrate it as much as possible,'' said Sister Kateri. ``I think it all depends how strong a teacher might be inclined toward spending the individual time, although there has been a definite push for this.'' For others, the King holiday underscores the need to include other cultures in school curriculum and textbooks. Clayborne Carson, a former civil rights activist who is editor of King's papers _ a 15-year project that is expected to result in publication of 12 volumes of King's writings and speeches _ said that in many schools the black history focus is merely token. ``It's like we created the occasion before we knew what we were going to do with it,'' said Carson, who is at American University this semester as a Visiting Landmarks Scholar in American History. ``It's going to be a long process moving from tokenism to meaningful content. We've just begun that process.'' Nannette McGee, consultant for social studies education in the Georgia Department of Education, said that although textbooks have been written about blacks in America, ``It just seems that ... they became old and out of date and they were not used because of that.'' Social studies textbooks have not been updated in five years, she said. Murdell McFarlin of the Atlanta Public Schools agreed. ``School officials aren't replacing the books right now because it's not the state-scheduled time, but they are supplementing them with essays and other information,'' said Mrs. McFarlin. Iowa in 1976 became the first state to pass a law mandating that school curriculum incorporate contributions of minorities and women. In New York, state Education Commissioner Thomas Sobol recently announced plans to draft broad revisions in the state's public school curriculum to give greater recognition to the contributions of non-white cultures to American society. The changes would affect the state's 2.5 million public schoolchildren. Ellen Swartz, multicultural project coordinator in the Rochester, N.Y., school district, said the district has been working for three years designing and producing classroom materials about groups that are usually misrepresented or omitted in textbooks and other educational materials. While most of the material developed is used voluntarily by the teachers, she said officials now are working on a ninth grade textbook on Africans. ``Rochester has taken a step past many districts that I've seen. Not in intent but in actions,'' said Ms. Swartz. ``What we are doing that's different is committing the resources and dollars. We are solidly on the cutting edge of movement in this area.'' Jack Gaffney, social studies program coordinator for the San Diego Unified School District, said the district tries to incorporate ``a strong multicultural strand'' into the curriculum ``all the way down through kindergarten.'' ``It's a matter of infusing things, where they would normally occur in history, in the curriculum to increase the depths of cultural studies,'' said Gaffney. Marlowe Teig, who for 22 years worked with a number of textbook publishers, said many schools are unable to puchase up-to-date textbooks that reflect black history. School and community officials also are not clear about what they want in the textbooks and fail to list the criteria, he added. Developing textbooks that reflect the role of blacks and others in American society is more than ``just mentioning all the leaders'' or ``taking a paragraph out and plugging another one in,'' he said. ``You have to be more reflective. Textbooks are not like USA Today. They don't line the garbage cans tomorrow. They are going to be around for years. They affect children's lives.''

DOC.HEAD: Reformed Communists, Opposition to Run National Slate
DOC.TEXT: The ruling Socialist Party and leading opposition groups have gained enough popular support under election laws to field national slates of candidates in the first general multiparty elections in more than 40 years, a newspaper reported Sunday. They are among 12 parties that will run candidates in the elections, set for March 25, according to the newspaper Mai Nap. There are more than 50 political parties. Candidates had to collect at least 750 signatures of eligible voters in their district to run. There are 176 individual districts, 152 regional districts and 58 seats on a national level. In most cases, if a party succeeds in fielding a candidate in 25 percent of the electoral districts of a given county or the capital city, then it could put up a county list. If it had a minimum of seven county lists, then it could put up a national list. A week before the Hungarian elections, East Germans will vote in the first free national balloting in the Soviet bloc. Among the Hungarian parties that will contest the elections nationally are the ruling Socialist Party, which was created from the former Communist party, and a newly constituted Communist Party. Non-leftist parties in the national running include the Hungarian Democratic Forum, the League of Free Democrats, and the Independent Smallholders.

DOC.HEAD: Governor Shuns Further Political Office
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Jim Martin has decided against seeking any elective office once his term ends in 1992, saying he wanted to preclude criticism that he was positioning himself for future campaigns. In a letter to The News & Observer published Sunday, Martin said he was embittered by what he viewed as unfair, partisan attacks by Democrats. ``Convinced that I can more effectively lead and work for a stronger North Carolina if my motives cannot be misrepresented, I am happy to sacrifice any further Martin candidacy,'' he said. The Republican governor also vigorously challenged news reports that criticized his performance at a Thursday news conference, in which he defended his Research Office against allegations that it engaged in tax-funded campaign activities. During that appearance, he at times appeared incoherent, uncharacteristically used profanity and disregarded the entreaties of aides who wanted him to stop talking. His staff attributed Martin's performance in part to medication he had taken for a throat infection. But in his letter to the newspaper, Martin said he had not taken medication before the news conference but that he was in ``agony'' from the illness. The governor said Saturday that although he was fighting the effects of a severe throat and sinus infection, he was in control. He said he would hold the news conference again under the same circumstances. Martin called the appearance the best day of his political career. ``It was my best, because I stood up on wobbly legs and suppressed my illness long enough to identify the Democrat investigators and newspaper who tried to destroy me before I ran again,'' he said. Martin lashed out at what he said was unfair treatment by Attorney General Lacy Thornburg and to a lesser extent by State Auditor Ed Renfrow, both Democrats. He said he was angry over reports that Thornburg was considering whether to investigate the governor's Research Office for possible political misuse of state property. Thornburg said Friday that his office would not investigate. Martin said it appeared that he was rambling during the news conference because he had been handed a note by an aide saying Thornburg had accepted his invitation for a confrontation at the news conference and was on his way. He said he didn't want to leave before Thornburg got there and be accused of a ``cowardly retreat.'' ``As weak as I was, I was going to stand my ground with him,'' Martin said. ``I had come to despise him. I was going to make him put the handcuffs on me right there in front of the reporters if that's what he wanted to do.'' But John Simmons, a spokesman for Thornburg, said Sunday that the attorney general never sent word that he would attend the news conference. Martin said he had decided against challenging U.S. Sen. Terry Sanford some time ago because he and his wife, Dorothy, had no desire to return to Washington, where he served 12 years in the House of Representatives. But he had planned to defer the announcement until after the 1990 elections to keep from becoming a lame duck and losing some of his political influence. By renouncing future political ambitions, Martin said he could work to solve the state's problems without having every move interpreted in the light of a possible Senate bid. ``After the way you piled on when I was down,'' he wrote in the letter to Claude Sitton, editor of The News & Observer, ``I know for certain that the only worthwhile ambition left for me is to root you and Lacy Thornburg out of North Carolina politics, along with any Democrats who take delight in your mischief.''

DOC.HEAD: Voting Peaceful At Border City Near Contra Camps
With AM-Nicaragua, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Voting was calm and orderly Sunday in this remote northern border outpost despite the presence of U.S.-supported Contra rebel bases only 20 miles away. ``This will mean political pluralism and everyone's participation,'' said Jose Burkhardo, 22, a supporter of te ruling Sandinista leftists, displaying his ink-stained left thumb with glee to prove he had voted. ``We want peace and a chance to rebuild the economy.'' There are about 14,400 voters in the Jalapa valley, which has 15 precincts in town and 21 in the outskirts. The valley, a productive agricultural area, is bordered on three sides by Honduras. Contra fighters have attacked the area in past years and there were frequent border incidents with Honduran troops, but the activity has died downsince the United States cut off lethal aid to the Contras in March of 1988. Contra leaders said they have ordered their troops to defend themselves but not to interfere with the voting. Lt. Antonio Diaz, an officer at the local military garrison where 3,500 soldiers are quartered, reported everything quiet on Sunday. He said the soldiers kept up routine patrols during the weeks leading up to the vote and there were no incidents. Observers from the Organization of American States were on hand to monitor the voting together with 30 Coloradans from the Boulder-Jalapa Friendship City Project Inc. of Boulder, Colo. ``I am very impressed. People are being businesslike,'' said Charlotte Houston, a Boulder County clerk who spent the day poll watching. ``They also enjoy seeing their neighbors at the polls like we do.'' Before voting began, election officials, representatives of the political parties and voters in line sang the national anthem. Bystanders were shown empty ballot boxes before voting commenced. ``The Sandinistas say everything will be better,'' United National Opposition supporter Maximiliano Sandoval said. ``For whom? We have had them for 10 years and what have we got? I am sure UNO will win.'' Antonio Huerta Vallejos, a local school teacher, did not agree. ``My school was built by the Sandinistas, so was the health center,'' he told a visiting reporter. ``It is important we vote for the (Sandinistas). ``Everything is in order and things are quiet. It is very clear it is a secret vote,'' he added.

DOC.HEAD: Woman With Experimental Pain Device Forced To Improvise After Theft
DOC.TEXT: When Loretta Born's purse was stolen, she lost more than money and ID cards. She lost a little magnet that's an important part of an experimental pain-control device. Born was forced to improvise Saturday night when her purse suddenly was missing after a stranger came to the door, ostensibly to ask for directions. But with the help of a neighbor's magnet and telephoned instructions from her doctor, Born was able to control the device implanted within her body. A nerve stimulator and the generator that powers it were surgically implanted in Born as part of an experimental treatment for pain that resulted from spinal injuries that she suffered in a car accident. Born's doctor, Robert Weiner, said fewer than 40 people in the country are using the device. Born said she would touch the magnet to the skin of her abdomen in order to turn off the power to the generator under her skin. If the stimulator runs too long, she said, ``it's painful and it causes my legs to jerk and makes it impossible for me to lie down.'' When the purse and magnet disappeared, Born contacted sheriff's Deputy Philip Escude, who called local hospitals and then contacted Weiner in Dallas. ``He told us that she would have to be brought back to Dallas unless somebody could find a magnet to turn her off,'' Escude said. Born said her husband borrowed a magnet from a neighbor. The magnet was larger and more powerful than the one she usually uses, so Weiner ``told me not to put it against my skin. First, we started out about six inches away, then four, then two inches. It finally cut off when we put the magnet about two inches away.'' Without the stimulator working right, Born said she is in pain. She said she was scared she might damage the equipment if she used the neighbor's magnet again, but she would have to wait until Monday to get another magnet from her doctor or hope the young woman who stole her purse returns her own magnet.

DOC.HEAD: Demonstrators Brave Soviet Police to Demand Democracy
With AM-Soviet-Rallies, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: For a while, it seemed like the old Soviet Union of the days before Mikhail Gorbachev and glasnost. ``We heard about tanks, about police waiting with gas and shovels,'' said one fearful middle-aged woman at a pro-democracy protest in the capital during nationwide demonstrations Sunday. Carrying a sign saying, ``We don't need a palace coup, we need direct elections,'' the woman was one of tens of thousands who marched past sand-filled dump trucks barricading all approaches to the Kremlin. About 17,000 police lay in wait with truncheons and water cannon. Protesters were clearly intimidated by authorities' warnings of the possibility of violence, promises of harsh penalties for extremists and reports that hospitals were prepared for many casualties. It didn't happen. The rally at the north end of the Garden Ring Road in Moscow started small and tentatively, with sidelong glances at rows of giant snowplows blocking exits from the parade route. However, one leader repeatedly promised police through a bullhorn, ``We represent no danger.'' Other protesters struck up conversations with individual officers to defuse tension. Gradually, it became clear that the army of police and Interior Ministry troops were not preparing to charge the protesters. Throngs of Muscovites joined the protest, which eventually included about 100,000 people. Red, blue and white flags of tsarist Russia fluttered in the occasional drizzle along with red and black flags of anarchists and the sky-blue cross on a white background of the Memorial Society, which is dedicated to remembering the victims of dictator Josef Stalin. Even the knots of police finally relaxed, stashing their riot gear. ``General, are you with the people?'' shouted a woman in the crowd to a stocky Interior Ministry officer directing crowd control at Gorky Park, one of the gathering points for the march. ``Sure, I am!'' replied Maj. Gen. Georgy Postoyuk. Contrary to widespread rumors that authorities planned to provoke violence to justify a crackdown, he said officials worked closely with rally organizers and the result was ``a very good, orderly meeting.'' The crowd count was much lower than organizers had predicted before the barrage of warnings. They included a television appeal by Minister of Culture Nikolai Gubenko, a popular actor, for cancellation of the demonstrations. Several planned counterdemonstrations of conservative and nationalist groups elsewhere in the city never materialized. Authorities even went so far as to broadcast a Polish film called ``The Sex Mission'' _ with nudity rare on Soviet television _ on Sunday morning. Protesting student Ivan Chemburov said he thought it was a deliberate attempt to entice people to stay home from the demonstration. Rally banners demanded multiparty elections and land for anyone who wants to work it. Some speakers drew loud applause as they called for the resignation of the entire Council of Ministers and the Communist Party Politburo. ``Communism is a cancerous tumor,'' said one poster. ``Party mafia _ resign! We've had enough of Marxist-Leninism. We want to live like people,'' read another. Protester Valentina Burakov said her father was killed in the Stalinist repression of the 1930s and she came to the meeting ``so this would never happen again.'' Parliamentarian Yuri Afanasiev called for transformation of the Soviet Union into a union of independent states. He warned that President Gorbachev's call for a strong presidency could restore totalitarianism.

DOC.HEAD: Trauma Center Closing Blamed Partly on Financial Losses From Gang Victims
DOC.TEXT: Mounting financial losses, caused in part by the cost of treating indigent gang-violence victims from neighboring Los Angeles, prompted the planned closing of a hospital trauma center, officials said. Huntington Memorial Hospital announced Friday it will close its emergency-care center at the end of April. The hospital, which lost $3.7 million last year, rejected Los Angeles County's offer of $1.6 million to offset losses if they would keep the trauma center open. ``It took a lot of careful soul-searching and debate to do this, but we simply could no longer afford to absorb the loss,'' said Allen W. Mathies Jr., the hospital's president and chief executive officer. ``We believe the trauma network is an important concept, but we can no longer sustain such a loss.'' Its closing leaves just 12 such centers in the county's trauma center network, down from 23 when the system opened in 1983. It is yet another instance in a national trend that's seeing the shutdown of more city hospitals offering special care for trauma, the medical name given to life-threatening injuries. In Miami, Chicago, Philadelphia and elsewhere, private hospitals have been shutting down trauma units, most of which opened in the mid-1980s, the specialty's boom years. Several emergency-care officials said Huntington's decision to close was prompted by complaints by hospital physicians about the lack of reimbursement for treating poor patients. Some doctors said they were tired of treating shooting victims from gang-plagued south-central Los Angeles, nearly 20 miles south of Pasadena, and other areas far away from the city of largely middle- and upper-class neighborhoods. ``You can't help but be unhappy that when you have a patient due for surgery and you have to postpone it to deal with a gunshot victim from south-central,'' said Dr. David Faddis, a surgeon at Huntington. ``Nobody was happy with the situation, but I'm sure most of the surgeons would agree that if they could have kept the trauma center open, they would have.''

DOC.HEAD: One Protest Disbanded, Other Held In `Cradle of Revolution'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RECASTS lead to CLARIFY that police moved against unauthorized rally; pickup graf 3 pvs, `In February...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Soviet-Rallies, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Riot police dragged away pro-democracy protesters to break up an unauthorized rally Sunday, but they allowed a sanctioned protest demanding that Soviet rulers give up their grip on power. About 8,000 people ignored rumors of impending violence and took part in the second rally, which officials authorized as part of nationwide protests demanding radical political and economic reforms. ``In February 1917, we started on the road to democracy. In October, we got dictatorship. Now there is a similar situation,'' Ilya Konstantinov, a candidate for the March 4 Russian parliamentary elections, told the crowd outside the Lenin Sports-Concert Complex. Leningrad, the site of three uprisings while it was capital of the Russian Empire, has been dubbed the ``cradle of revolution.'' In 1905, czarist forces fired on demonstrators demanding democratic reforms in a clash known as ``Bloody Sunday.'' Sunday was the anniversary of another uprising, the 1917 February Russian Revolution, in which bourgeois-democratic forces seized power and forced Czar Nicholas II to abdicate. The Bolshevik Communists, led by Vladimir I. Lenin, took over eight months later. Leningrad, the country's second-largest city with 5 million residents, has been a political hotspot ever since, and on Sunday was in the spotlight again. An hour before the rally at the sports complex, about a dozen activists in the Democratic Union, a radical group fighting to end the Communist Party's grip on power, gathered on a square outside the Young Spectators Theater. As a column of 100 police surrounded the crowd and KGB plainclothes agents stood by, an officer approached and shouted through a megaphone that no demonstration was authorized. A dozen riot police wearing white helmets and green bulletproof vests then stormed in and dragged away several of the activists, who had no protest posters and had not made any public statements. The activists, some carried by the police, were loaded onto buses for detention. A parliamentary candidate and Associated Press photographer Dominique Mollard also were taken away but later released after their identification documents were checked. One activist climbed atop a yellow construction crane and unfurled a cloth banner that referred to the March 4 elections. ``Boycott _ It's your First Step to Freedom!'' it read. He threw to the crowd below slips of paper that carried the same slogan along with, ``Participation in elections allows a continuation of the 72-year experiment on Russia.'' It was signed, Democratic Union. Five riot police quickly mounted the crane and dragged down the protester. Posters at the sports complex later also urged a boycott of the elections and one used a 1917 quote from Lenin to attack the current leadership. ``At the top is shame and disorder. The party in power protects its scoundrels,'' read a red banner with white letters hanging on the marble speaker's platform. Writer Mikhail Chulaky, a member of the grass-roots group People's Front, told the crowd huddling on a wet parking lot under a gray, rainy sky that the Communist Party's decision earlier this month to end its monopoly on power was long overdue and added: ``The party of genocide must be disbanded, like (Germany's Nazi party) was disbanded by Nuremberg.'' Several speakers attacked President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's proposal to strengthen his powers as president. ``Again they are wrapping a dictator around our necks,'' said Nikolai Ivanov, a Soviet parliamentarian from Leningrad whose crusade against official corruption has made him immensely popular. A protest banner equated the presidency with fascism, a powerful comparison in a city where 600,000 people were killed by the Nazis in World War II. A resolution passed by a show of demonstrators' hands and a resounding ``Da!'' said the president should be chosen by the people, not the party apparatus, and urged voters on March 4 to elect pro-democracy candidates and ``tear power from the apparatus.'' Leaders of The People's Front, Leningrad's biggest pro-democracy group, decided to boycott the rally because they feared retaliation from either the government or right-wing groups. Dissenting People's Front members showed up and harshly condemned their leaders' decision. Police and plainclothes KGB agents stood by and did not interfere in the rally and there were no incidents.

DOC.HEAD: 150,000 Bulgarians Demand Democracy, Ouster of Communists
DOC.TEXT: More than 150,000 people, chanting ``Enough of the nightmare!'' rallied Sunday in the largest challenge to the Communist regime since hard-line leader Todor Zhivkov was ousted in November. Participants at the rally in Sofia, the capital, also chanted ``Down with the Communist Party!'' and called for democracy. The crowd, whose size was estimated by Western reporters, gathered despite a Communist attempt to defuse popular discontent by agreeing to concessions sought by opposition parties. The party's Supreme Council on Friday announced it will ban Communist cells in places of work; postpone general elections from May to June, giving the opposition more time to prepare; and invite foreign observers to monitor the voting. Meantime, the Communist Party is in sole control of government. Despite reforms, it has resisted compromise with opposition forces more than Communists in other Eastern European countries. The protesters, who gathered in unseasonably balmy weather in the square in front of party headquarters, cheered as opposition leader Petko Simeonov declared: ``The winter of our discontent is at an end! The spring of our struggle has begun!'' On Friday, the Supreme Council suggested upgrading suspended talks with the opposition to a ``permanently functioning general political forum'' to prepare for a transition to democracy. But opposition speakers were critical Sunday. ``The Communist Party wants to improve the image of the round table, but at the same time it is putting important draft laws before Parliament behind our backs,'' said Zheljo Zhelev, who heads the Union of Democratic Forces, which respresents the nation's major opposition movements. The Communists plan to introduce draft legislation at the next session of the party-controlled Parliament that deals with constitutional amendments and changes to electoral and party laws. The Parliament session opens March 5 and will be carried live by state radio and television. Zhelev demanded that representatives to the talks have a say on the legislation. Simeonov described Sunday's rally as the official start of the opposition's election campaign, and other speakers proclaimed plans to hold more mass meetings in an effort to get concessions from the Communists. Speakers at the rally also called for private property and a market economy.
