In one of the high points of the rally, the crowd accepted by a show-of-hands vote on a resolution calling on Bulgarians to ``break with more than four decades of totalitarianism and to distance themselves from everything that is socialistic.'' Rally participants, in a symbolic gesture, changed the name of the square where they had gathered from Sept. Square _ after the date in 1944 when a national front dominated by the Communists took over _ to Democracy Square.

DOC.HEAD: Ivory Coast Heeds Church and Frees Student Protesters
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with warning from official, reporters detained, presidential meeting postponed; no pickup.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Ivory Coast
DOC.TEXT: The government, under pressure from the Roman Catholic Church, Sunday freed more than 150 pro-democracy student protesters who were beaten and detained after a 10-hour occupation of Abidjan Cathedral. ``We are happy that we secured their release,'' Abbot Athenase Ake said as freed students fell to their knees before him, kissing his hand in thanks. But state television said President Felix Houphouet-Boigny pardoned the students out of his ``love of the country's youth.'' In the first official comment on weeklong student protests that have led to violent clashes with police, Internal Security Minister Youssouf Koffi said demonstrators are being ``manipulated by self-serving bandits with ulterior motives.'' He claimed 70 protesters detained during the unrest were not university students. ``The disorder will stop,'' he said. The students freed Sunday raised clenched fists and sang the national anthem, ``Greetings, Land of Promise,'' in front of the police station. They said they would continue Monday with pro-democracy protests, which pose the most serious challenge in years to the conservative government of Houphouet-Boigny. The university students say they are angered by the gulf between rich and poor in this West African nation. They say government officials live lavishly while ordinary citizens suffer. The students are demanding that Houphouet-Boigny step down and make way for a multiparty democracy. He has ruled the Ivory Coast as a one-party state since its independence from France in 1960. Ake told reporters that Roman Catholic officials felt responsible for the detention of the students because they left the cathedral Saturday after clergymen there were assured the students would be allowed to go free. The students were beaten and detained when they left the cathedral. The dispute threatens normally close relations between the church and the embattled government of Houphouet-Boigny, an ardent Catholic. State television also announced the postponement until Tuesday of a meeting between Houphouet-Boigny, legislators and representatives of businesses, trade unions and professional organizations. The meeting, which was to have been held Monday, is to discuss the economic crisis caused by slumping cocoa and coffee prices, the cornerstones of Ivory Coast's once-thriving economy. One delegate said the president is expected to announce more of the austerity measures that have angered students. But the delegate, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the president also may meet one student demand by announcing salary cuts for Cabinet ministers. Employees at state-owned companies had their salaries cut 30 percent this month, and the students want the ministers' pay reduced by that amount. Other civil servants have had their salary levels frozen for eight years. In another development, police detained two reporters of the British-based Reuters international news agency for a few hours Sunday when they were found talking with students. Police have threatened foreign reporters covering the protests. On Saturday, university and high school students stoned buses and cars in Yopougoun, forcing police and soldiers to temporarily cut bus service to the working-class suburb where the unrest began at a university residence the night of Feb. 19. At that time, students set two cars ablaze and were attacked by police firing tear gas and wielding truncheons.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands of Demonstrators, Police Turn Out For Moscow Rallies
LaserPhotos MOSB3,5,13
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 26th graf, `Elsewhere, local...' to UPDATE with details of Georgia protest. Pick up 27th pvs, `In Kiev...'
DOC.TEXT: From Siberia to the southern republic of Georgia, hundreds of thousands of Soviets rallied for democracy in more than 30 cities Sunday, despite official warnings that the Soviet Union's first nationwide protest could explode in violence. More than 100,000 people turned out in Moscow, and smaller protests occurred elsewhere. The official warnings, which were repeated frequently last week in the state-run media, kept the turnout low in some cities and prevented some protests altogether. Riot police dragged away people who tried to hold an unsanctioned demonstration in Leningrad, but there were no reports of major unrest. In Moscow, the crowd grew through the afternoon as initial tension gave way to a relaxed and good-natured atmosphere. One column of marchers was led by a man with a bullhorn who told police and bystanders, ``We represent no danger.'' Gavril Popov, a member of the Congress of People's Deputies and one of the organizers of the demonstration day, told masses gathered under cloudy skies that the Communist Party and state apparatus had engineered a campaign of fear not seen since Stalin in an attempt to thwart the outpouring of popular sentiment. The protests were planned after a successful Feb. 4 pro-democracy rally in Moscow in which about 200,000 people demanded the Communist Party give up its monopoly on power. The party did so shortly afterward. Thousands of uniformed police and internal security troops guarded the authorized march route along the broad Garden Ring Road that circles the city center. Sand-filled dump trucks, water trucks and snowplows sealed off all roads leading from the Garden Ring Road into the downtown area where the Kremlin and Red Square were guarded by more police posted about every 30 feet. Estimates of the number of protesters varied widely, from 200,000 reported by the official press agency Novosti, which had a view of the rally site in Moscow, to a half-million claimed by Popov. An independent newsletter issued by Radio Moscow quoted unnamed Interior Ministry officials as putting the crowd at 300,000. Maj. Gen. Georgy Postoyuk of the Interior Ministry, who said he was in charge of security at Gorky Park, estimated 100,000 people gathered at the park. They then marched across a bridge over the Moscow River and met up with a considerably smaller group that had gathered at the Foreign Ministry. Together, they headed to the rally site. Reports from police, local activists interviewed by telephone and state-run media indicated as many as 276,000 people took part in protest rallies in 32 cities outside Moscow, from Petropavlovsk-Kamchatky in the Soviet Far East to Leningrad on the Baltic Sea coast. ``All was against us,'' Popov told the crowd in Moscow's Zubovsky Square. ``The City Council was late in announcing the site, time, routes. Television has special entertainment shows on. The authorities have waged a campaign of stepping up tensions, hysteria, rumors, provocations and libel unheard of since 1937,'' when Stalin's campaign of terror reached its height, Popov said. With banners, placards and flags, the demonstrators demanded democratic reforms ranging from direct popular election of the president to a multiparty system. Speakers urged them to endorse progressive candidates running in March 4 parliamentary elections in the Russian federation and demanded the ouster of members of the ruling Politburo and Council of Ministers, as well as KGB chief Vladimir A. Kryuchkov. With a massive show of hands, the crowd voted in support of a platform presented by historian and parliament deputy Yuri Afanasyev that proposed a direct presidential election, estabishment of private property and the turning over state-run media from party control to editorial collectives. ``We're fed up with how we live,'' said one demonstrator, Celestine Langovaya, a music teacher in her 50s. ``When (Mikhail S.) Gorbachev first came to power, I believed in him, but things have gotten worse for millions of people.'' Security forces were much in evidence, but more battalions were held in reserve on side streets and just out of sight behind buildings and in walled construction sites. A special information center of the Novosti Press Agency said 100,000 people gathered on Lenin Square in Minsk, the Byelorussian capital, for the largest turnout reported outside the Soviet capital. Only about 8,000 demonstrators showed up at the officially authorized rally site in Leningrad, the nation's second-largest city. Leaders of the pro-independence People's Front movement there had urged followers to boycott the event because authorities would not grant permission to demonstrate in a downtown street. Riot police far outnumbered a small group that did try to demonstrate downtown without official permission. Officers broke up the attempted protest and dragged demonstrators aboard waiting buses. In Riga, Latvia's capital, no rallies were held for fears of provoking reprisals by troops, said Uldis Smit of the Latvian People's Front. Authorities in the southern Russian city of Rostov-on-Don refused to allow any rallies, and about 100 dismayed activists gathered near the local Communist Party headquarters to hand out leaflets, the official Tass news agency said. Military authorities in Azerbaijan banned all demonstrations, fearing a renewal of the nationalist violence that led to ethnic warfare between Armenians and Azerbaijanis in January. About 2,000 were said to have gathered in the central Siberian city of Krasnoyarsk, but activists there said many people went to the wrong places because state-controlled media had refused to report plans for the rally. Elsewhere, local activists said 50,000 people rallied in Georgia's capital of Tbilisi and 12,000 in the large Siberian city of Novosibirsk. Another 18,000 people attended two rallies in the Urals city of Sverdlovsk, they said. In Tbilisi, the demonstrators tore down street signs of a street named after Lenin and renamed it for a prominent Georgian dissident killed in a car crash last year, a political activist said. In Kiev, 50,000 Ukrainians gathered, said Victor Linchevsky, a spokesman for the grassroots organization Rukh. An angry crowd later prevented police from detaining three activists, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Opens Up
DOC.TEXT: The dollar opened at 147.50 yen on the Tokyo foreign exchange market Monday, up from Friday's close of 146.47 yen.

DOC.HEAD: PRECEDES Christchurch
Father Arrives In New Zealand To Reclaim Daughter
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout with father arriving in New Zealand, charges traded by father and mother, details; no pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY39
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. doctor arrived in New Zealand Monday to try to reclaim his 7-year-old daughter, who is at the center of a bitter custody battle and reportedly has not seen either of her parents for two years. The girl's mother, Dr. Jean Elizabeth Morgan, was jailed for 25 months in August 1987, when she refused to say where her daughter was after a U.S. court gave her former husband unsupervised access to the child. Morgan, a 42-year-old plastic surgeon in Washington, had claimed her ex-husband, Dr. Eric Foretich, sexually abused the child, a charge he denies. Morgan sent the girl, Hilary Foretich, away with her maternal grandparents, first to England, then to Christchurch, to prevent her father from seeing her. But Foretich announced Saturday he had located the girl in Christchurch, where she has been living for nearly two years. Morgan reportedly accused him of hunting Hilary down ``like an animal.'' Foretich flew from Washington, D.C., into Mangere International Airport on the North Island and was to fly to Christchurch in the south for a family court hearing, according to the New Zealand Press Association. ``Certainly, we're going to do what we need to do to rescue my daughter,'' the Press Association quoted him as saying. Morgan is unable to travel to New Zealand because her passport was taken from her when she went to jail. She was released in September. Hilary was allowed to speak to her mother by telephone Sunday for the first time in two years, her family said. ``When she talked to her mother, she broke down in tears,'' said her maternal grandmother, Antonia Morgan. ``We've got letters to us through various channels, but this was the first time she had spoken on the phone to her.'' Before he boarded the flight, Foretich, of Falls Church, Va., reportedly accused his former wife of waging a media campaign against him. ``I think Elizabeth Morgan and the people who follow her are very misguided people by the way they're going to make it difficult for my daughter, and it's really a shame,'' said Foretich, a 45-year-old dental surgeon. ``My daughter deserves to come back and have a normal life,'' Radio New Zealand quoted Foretich as saying. The mother flung back her own charges, claiming her former husband sought publicity himself, according to the New Zealand Press Association. ``Eric is the one who has had a publicity agent for I think six months to a year, not me.'' ``He has hunted her down like an animal. She does not want to see him, and he knows that,'' the agency said, quoting her from the United States. William Morgan, the child's maternal grandfather, told Television New Zealand he would call the police if Foretich tried to approach Hilary. ``He can't do it. I would have to call the police because the court order says he can't,'' he said. The Family Court in Christchurch granted an interim order on Friday giving the maternal grandparents custody of Hilary. Police in New Zealand said attorneys for Foretich lost a bid for interim custody of Hilary in the Christchurch Family Court on Friday. The mother's lawyer predicted this latest stage in the battle would be drawn out. ``Certainly (there will be) several weeks of preparation and perhaps two or three months before we have a hearing before the family court in Christchurch,'' said Lyn Stevens. The court refused to comment on the case or say when a hearing would be held. Foretich will have to ``start from scratch'' in the Family Court custody battle for Hilary, despite the U.S. order giving him visitation rights, said Geoff Ellis, a family court lawyer not involved in the case. ``The guardianship law in New Zealand is child-centered rather than parentally,'' he said Monday. Hilary's mother is also believed to be trying to fly to Christchurch, but she must first go to court to win the return of her passport. A swarm of American journalists was expected to arrive in New Zealand to cover the case, which is one of the best-known custody battles in the United States. The couple wed in January 1982 but separated seven months later, a week before Hilary was born. They obtained a divorce that November on the Carribean island of Haiti, where the marriage took place. Bitter wrangling over Foretich's rights to visit the child started in 1985, when she was 2{-years old. Accusing him of sexual abuse, Morgan sought a court order to suspend the visits between father and daughter. In November of that year, Judge Herbert Dixon in the Washington Superior Court found there was inconclusive evidence of abuse. Morgan was also unsuccessful in a federal court jury trial in mid-1986, which she initiated through a civil lawsuit against her former husband.

DOC.HEAD: Some Indelible Ink Doesn't Do the Trick
With AM-Nicaragua, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with details, color. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Some of the indelible ink being used to mark voters' fingers as a safeguard against multiple voting is not so indelible, the head of the Supreme Electoral Council admitted Sunday. But the official, Mariano Fiallos, said there were other safeguards against a citizen voting more than once and there was no evidence of abuse. In a live TV interview, Fiallos said some of the special ink could be taken off with common laundry bleach. The ink was supposed to stain for three days. Fiallos did not specify to how many of the 4,394 polling places nationwide the faulty ink had been distributed, saying only that ``some of the inkpots'' were at fault. Opposition vice presidential candidate Virgilio Godoy held up a clean thumb at a news conference and said he'd been able to wash his finger after voting. He said the opposition had received scattered reports from Managua and the provincial capital of Matagalpa on the problem. ``That's something that's being investigated,'' said Dan Evans, a former senator from Washington state who is here as part of former President Jimmy Carter's observation team. ``We're tracking that down. And I doubt it very much if very many people would be involved in that.'' Several voters interviewed by The Associated Press said they had been unable to wash off the ink, and two voters who were asked to try to wash the ink off with soap and water were unable to do so. However, a test with common bleach did remove the ink. One voter said he had tried taking the ink off with gasoline and it would not come off. Others said they had tried lemon or melon juice or cola. Voters who had marked thumbs were showing them off to each other, proud of having voted.

DOC.HEAD: Unconventional Designer to Roll Out New Low-Tech Combat Jet
DOC.TEXT: Unconventional airplane designer Burt Rutan, whose Voyager flew around the world without refueling, has built a new combat jet that flies in the face of the high-tech, high-cost aviation design ethic. The first test model of the new plane, named Ares, will be rolled out Monday at Rutan's Scaled Composites Inc. at Mojave Airport in the California high desert. The plane, intended to provide ``minimum complexity, maintenance and acquisition costs,'' is aimed more at foreign markets than the high-tech U.S. military and its expensive aircraft. Rutan's Scaled Composites developed the jet for about $2 million, a fraction of the normal development cost of a military plane. Designed as a light attack aircraft, the twin-tailed Ares is constructed of composite materials and powered by a single turbofan engine. Composites are construction materials such as graphite and epoxy that offer strength without the weight of traditional aviation metals. The most distinctive outward feature is the Rutan specialty, a canard, a small wing forward of the main wing that increases stability. The name comes from the Greek god of war but is used as an acronym for agile, responsive, effective support. The jet was designed to be armed with a 25mm gun and serve a primary role in close air support and against helicopters. It could also be armed with air-to-air and air-to-ground missiles. A two-seat version is envisioned for forward air control and training missions. Ares is also suggested for border patrol and reconnaissance duties as well as drug interdiction missions. Overseas sales are the most likely marketing option. The U.S. Air Force has its sights on high-performance, high-capability jets like the F-16 and the developing stealth aircraft technology. The Army has focused its aviation strategy on helicopters. Rutan gained worldwide fame for designing Voyager, the delicate, slender airplane that his brother, Dick, and copilot Jeana Yeager flew around the world non-stop on a single tank of fuel. Other planes had flown around the world by being refueled in flight, but none had ever made it on their own. Rutan used composite carbon-fiber honeycomb materials for light weight, a canard and fuel-stingy engines to give Voyager the ability to keep itself aloft for the nine-day, 25,000-mile flight in December 1986.

DOC.HEAD: Restoration Of Diplomatic Ties Expected During Foreign Minister's Visit
DOC.TEXT: Poland and Israel are expected to restore full diplomatic relations during a visit by Israeli Foreign Minister Moshe Arens, who was to arrive Monday. The official PAP news agency said Poland's decision to restore ties, broken in 1967, acknowledges the error of the decision to sever them and its consequences, including an anti-Semitic purge in 1968. All Warsaw Pact nations except Romania cut diplomatic relations with Israel after the 1967 Middle East war, when Israel occupied Arab territory. Poland will be the second country to restore ties, after Hungary, which took the step last September. Polish-Israeli relations have steadily improved since 1986, when each country established an interest section in the other's capital. The interest sections, initially maintained through a second country with full diplomatic standing, were elevated to diplomatic missions on Jan. 1, 1989. ``The period of abnormality in our contacts is over and now we should simply embark on building the new structure of relations and fill it with concrete contents,'' Mordechai Palzur, head of the Israeli mission in Warsaw, told the Zycie Warszawy newspaper last week. History has given Polish-Israeli contacts a ``special character,'' Palzur said. More than 3.5 million Jews lived in prewar Poland, 3 million of whom were killed by the Nazis during the World War II occupation. Most of the 500,000 who survived emigrated after the war or following waves of anti-Semitism, the most significant of which came in 1968 as a result of an internal political struggle. There are now only several thousand Jews in Poland. Poland is ready to ``welcome back'' those who emigrated and restore Polish citizenship, PAP said. In addition, the agency said, Poland is prepared to consider compensation for the emigres, although negotiations have not begun. Poland's new Solidarity-led government is pursuing a course of evenhanded diplomacy in the Middle East, and is seeking improved relations with Arab nations, a Foreign Ministry official, Krzysztof Plominski, said in a recent interview. Since September, Poland has established relations for the first time with the United Arab Emirates, Oman and Katar. Last year, Poland withdrew a small stipend it provided to the Palestinian Liberation Organization's diplomatic mission in Warsaw. However, Foreign Minister Krzysztof Skubiszewski, meeting Arab diplomts in January, assured them that Poland supports the Palestinians' right to a homeland.

DOC.HEAD: Aquino Criticizes Enrile on Anniversary of Revolution
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS three grafs to UPDATE with Enrile response, ADD background on alleged links to coup attempt; pickup 7th graf pvs, `Never have...'
DOC.TEXT: President Corazon Aquino thanked thousands of cheering people Sunday for supporting her during repeated coup attempts and accused an opposition senator of plotting against her. Speaking on the fourth anniversary of the revolution that toppled President Ferdinand Marcos and brought her to power, Mrs. Aquino told 30,000 people: ``No matter how great the threats are, we will thwart their dark plans.'' Mrs. Aquino, who has survived six coup attempts, denounced opposition Sen. Juan Ponce Enrile, saying he was trying to rewrite the history of the military-civilian revolt on Feb. 22-25, 1986, that became known as the ``people power'' uprising. The rebellion began with a military mutiny, led by then-Defense Minister Enrile, that eventually succeeded when hundreds of thousands of civilians poured into the streets to protect mutineers from Marcos' tanks. In a radio interview Sunday, Mrs. Aquino said the Enrile alliance was a ``shotgun marriage'' that fell apart because of plots against her. Enrile was fired as a minister in November 1986 after a failed coup by his followers. On Friday, he ``apologized'' for having helped install Mrs. Aquino. On Sunday, Enrile told reporters that he would not ``answer her in equal measure'' for her denunciation of him. In a statement, Enrile also said he felt ``sorry for her for getting too emotional in discussing issues.'' Last month, the National Bureau of Investigation recommended rebellion charges against Enrile for alleged links to a December coup attempt. Enrile denied the charge, and a panel of government lawyers investigating the coup attempt has not decided whether to indict the senator. ``Never have I heard of such a thing as an `Enrile power' revolution,'' Mrs. Aquino told the cheering crowd. ``I will talk to Mr. Enrile or his minions if they are listening: Mr. Enrile, have you no shame?'' She said that without popular support, Enrile and his supporters would have been crushed by Marcos and that Enrile ``gets very nervous in a crisis.'' ``Be a man,'' she added. ``Or better yet, be a woman.'' She thanked the people for their support, saying, ``Without you, Enrile could have harmed me and I would not be president now. You did not abandon me.'' She noted that four years ago, Enrile had admitted to massive cheating in the Feb. 7, 1986, election in which Marcos was proclaimed the winner by his rubber-stamp Parliament. Enrile also admitted faking an ambush on himself in 1972, which Marcos used as a pretext for declaring eight years of martial law. Mrs. Aquino called Enrile ``the great kibitzer'' who ``wanted to grab the ball as soon as his team was losing and be team captain himself,'' a reference to his abandoning Marcos in 1986. ``The problem with kibitzers is that they get very nervous in a crisis,'' she said. ``So because of his fear of Marcos, he called on the people's help, and we remember him confessing to all his sins.'' More than 5,000 troops were deployed around Manila during the outdoor rally because of continuing threats by restive members of the military, many of whom played key roles in the 1986 mutiny but later broke with Mrs. Aquino.

DOC.HEAD: International Trans-Antarctica Trek Prepares For Saturday Photo Finish
DOC.TEXT: Polar explorer Will Steger is little more than 100 miles from achieving his goal: crossing Antarctica's 3,600 miles by ski and dog sled. ``We're on the home stretch,'' Steger, 45, said Friday on the trail in an interview published in Sunday's St. Paul Pioneer Press Dispatch. ``Unless we fall into a crevasse, we should be OK.'' Welcome banners have been readied for Saturday, and snow has been plowed flat at the finish line at Mirnyy, the Soviet science station overlooking the icebergs and penguin colonies of the Indian Ocean. Scientists will converge in the station's kitchen this week to make miniature Russian dumplings as a treat for members of the expedition, which has its headquarters in St. Paul. U.S. scientists feted Steger's group when it reached the South Pole on Dec. 11, the first dog sled trek to the bottom of the world since Roald Amundsen arrived there on Dec. 14, 1911. Steger made history four years ago when he led a similar assault on the North Pole. The six men could have finished the seven-month International Trans-Antarctica Expedition five days ahead of schedule. But their long-awaited finale is being delayed two days past Steger's self-imposed deadline of Thursday because of contracts with television stations around the world. Most notably, a Soviet-French consortium plans to broadcast the expedition's finish live from the Antarctic coast at Mirnyy. ABC-TV Sports may show clips of the finish on ``Wide World of Sports'' Saturday.

DOC.HEAD: North Korea Accuses United States of Lies
DOC.TEXT: North Korea said Sunday that a U.S. State Department report accusing it of violating human rights is full of slander and ``whopping lies.'' ``The U.S. imperialists are exploiting every means and method possible to impair the high international prestige of (North Korea) and block worldwide support and sympathy for its unique socialist system,'' said a commentary in he official Communist Party newspaper Rodong Shinmun. The commentary, broadcast in part by Pyongyang's Korean Central News Agency, monitored in Tokyo, followed a U.S. State Department report last week on human rights around the world. The report's section on North Korea said that country ``continues to deny its citizens the most fundamental human rights.'' Rodong Shinmun declared: ``The United States is a graveyard of human rights, and U.S. imperialism is the most heinous violator of human rights in the world and the ringleader of state terrorism. It is ridiculous, indeed, for them to charge others with `violation of human rights.''' It described the U.S. report as ``vilifying (North Korea) with whopping lies.'' Noting that the report also denounced the human rights records of China and Cuba, Rodong Shinmun said: ``With no intrigue and slander, however, can the U.S. imperialists block the road of the countries which advance under the banner of socialism and anti-imperialist independence.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Treasury Secretary Asked to Push Aid Through to Poland
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady reviewed the government's plan for economic reform in talks Sunday with finance officials, who asked him to speed up pledged U.S. aid, the official news agency reported. Brady said during the one-day visit that the United States seeks ``to support the processes striving for restoring a market-oriented economy in Eastern Europe'' but must see proof that the nations will stick to severe reform steps, the news agency PAP said. ``We have to be convinced about the constant nature of the changes that are under way,'' Brady said in an interview with PAP. He said all avenues for aid to Poland are still open, ``but one has to assess their effectiveness first.'' Poland's finance minister, Leszek Balcerowicz, told PAP that he discussed with Brady the ``acceleration'' of U.S. aid, especially for programs to develop private enterprise and expand exports. Polish officials have been asking to begin drawing on a $45 million U.S. enterprise fund. Poland's $40 billion debt to the West was also discussed. Poland owes about $3.1 billion of that amount to the United States. The government, led by the Solidarity labor movement, is seeking moratoriums on payments and reduction of the overall debt as a crucial part of the effort to salvage the shattered economy and reshape it as a market-driven system. The Polish debt is expected to be a key topic during Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki's trip to Washington in mid-March. Brady's stop in Warsaw followed last week's two-day visit by U.S. Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence Eagleburger, who was appointed by President Bush to coordinate aid programs for Poland.

DOC.HEAD: Last Body Recovered in Ice Accident That Killed 7
DOC.TEXT: Divers on Sunday recovered the body of the last of seven people killed when a members of a youth group and four would-be rescuers fell through thin ice into a lake. The body of Dave ``Grandpa'' Meyers was retrieved from Convict Lake in the eastern Sierra Nevada range, said a Mono County sheriff's dispatcher. The body was spotted by a sophisticated underwater video camera lowered into the lake Wednesday, but divers were unable to recover the remains until Sunday. The bodies of the six other people killed in the accident Feb. 19 were recovered previously. Meyers, 53, of Bishop, was a counselor at a home for delinquents and youths who have committed minor violations. Killed in the accident were three teen-age boys from the camp, Meyers and another counselor who went to their aid, and two other rescuers. The lake is 250 miles north of Los Angeles.

DOC.HEAD: Governors Told Not To Assume Peace Dividend
DOC.NOTE: EDS: INSERTS 4 new grafs after 10th graf to UPDATE with toasts at White House; picks up 11th graf pvs, Among the xxx; deletes pvs 18th graf, now redundant; edits at bottom to tighten
DOC.TEXT: The nation's governors put their stamp Sunday on national education goals, but got no encouragement from the White House for the prospect of financial help from a ``peace dividend.'' ``Our aim is excellence in education,'' said Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, as he offered the goals to the National Governors' Association for approval. The Arkansas Democrat added that ``I do not believe we will achieve them (the goals) unless we dramatically change our behavior.'' The changes referred to by Clinton were included in a series of objectives that would put the governors on record as pressing for specific steps toward implementing the goals first outlined by President Bush in his State of the Union address last month. The governors also adopted a resolution urging the president to allocate any defense budget savings toward education as well as reducing the federal budget deficit and other domestic needs. ``We have to get this peace dividend,'' said Gov. Roy Romer of Colorado ``or else we're going to have to make some other change in this country's policies or else we're not going to close the gap that we've created.'' Romer worked with fellow Democratic Gov. Mario Cuomo of New York in drafting the resolution. Cuomo did not attend the NGA session. The resolution called on the president ``to dedicate the peace dividend in a balanced manner between the federal budget deficit, education and other productivity investments.'' Earlier, Romer failed in an attempt to get the governors to adopt a resolution that urged the president to ``direct substantial federal resources from defense to educational needs and other productivity investments.'' ``Otherwise, I don't believe we are going to get the attention of the federal establishment in helping us meet the goals we have today,'' Romer said. At a state dinner at the White House, Bush toasted the governors and what he called ``our commitment to work together toward ... an American education system that is second to none.'' ``We came together not as Republicans and Democrats, not as partisan competitors, but as fellow chief executives with our hearts and minds focused on a single goal: the future of our kids, the future of our country,'' said Bush. Iowa Gov. Terry Branstad, the governors' chairman, said, ``We all expect that there's a lot of work ahead of us.'' He raised his glass to both the president and Barbara Bush, saying, ``I think we recognize that the first lady may have had some influence on the president in this area.'' The governors were returning to the White House Monday to meet with Bush. Among the earliest reaction to the governors' action was sharp criticism from Timothy J. Dyer, executive director of the National Association of Secondary School Principals. ``America's governors receive an A-plus for rhetoric, but fail economics,'' said Dyer. ``Their goals are lofty, patriotic, noble and certainly what we all would like. However, without resources they are merely wishes.'' The governors also heard an appeal from four mayors for more resources for their efforts to combat drugs. The mayors sought the governors' support in allowing some federal funds for drug programs to go directly to major cities rather than be channeled through the state governments. Testifying were Mayors Richard L. Berkley of Kansas City, Mo.; W. Wilson Goode of Philadelphia; Sue Myrick of Charlotte, N.C.; and Maureen O'Connor of San Diego. ``Get those federal dollars where they're needed most,'' appealed Goode. ``We mayors want direct funding for cities because it doesn't always get to us,'' said Myrick. The educational objectives were drafted in consultation with the White House and were broad enough to be acceptable to all. But on the touchier question of how to pay for improved education, the governors got no commitments from Richard G. Darman, the White House budget director. Darman reminded the governors that the budget Bush sent to Congress for the next fiscal year included a $500 million increase in federal funding for the Head Start program. But beyond that, Darman would only say that ``the political system is going to have to have its debate over the division of responsibility.'' Romer contended that for the past 50 years the federal government had been taking a growing share of the nation's tax base and using much of it for national security. ``I firmly believe the threat to our security is no longer superior military forces,'' Romer said. ``It is inadequate skill levels.'' ``You have the tax base, we've got the problem,'' the Colorado governor said. Romer asked Darman if he would consider taking a percentage of federal tax receipts and sending it to the states to be used as state officials decide. ``I'll be happy to have us look at any specific proposal,'' Darman replied. ``I'm not entirely sure I agree with your premise.'' Democratic Gov. Richard Celeste of Ohio asked Darman about some $250 billion of unexpended Pentagon obligations that might no longer be needed. The budget director said those Pentagon funds were in contracts which require the government to pay a penalty if it cancels them. He said the savings ``won't be anywhere near the number that you mentioned.'' The education goals called for improvement in pre-school programs so that ``all children in America will start school ready to learn.'' Others called for increasing the high school graduation rate to 90 percent and improving student competency in subjects such as English, mathematics, science, history and geography.

DOC.HEAD: Yugloslav Expatriate Murdered in Bulgium
DOC.TEXT: Gunmen ambushed and killed a leading Yugoslav expatriate as he sat in his car in a suburb Sunday afternoon, police reported. Witnesses told police that several men shot Enver Hadri, chairman of the Belgian Committee for Human Rights in Kosovo, in his car in the Brussels suburb of Saint Gilles. Hadri died about four hours later at a nearby hospital, police said. Witnesses told police the murderers fled in a Volkswagen. Other expatriates from the Yugoslav province of Kosovo, quoted by the Belgian news agency Belga, said it was a political murder. However, there were no details. Kosovo is a southern region of Serbia, but the majority of the population is of Albanian origin and wants more freedom from the central government. The province has been the scene of riots and protests reflecting tensions between Serbs and ethnic Albanians.

DOC.HEAD: Fence Separating Blacks from Whites in Cemetery Is Ordered Down
DOC.TEXT: A fence separating poorly tended graves for blacks from nicely kept graves for whites must come down, says a judge who further ordered an end to 125 years of unequal upkeep in a private cemetery. Lebanon's blacks call the back of Ryder Cemetery ``the jungle'' because weeds, trash and brambles have overrun the more than 200 graves of their loved ones. On the other side of a rusty wire fence are graves for whites with gleaming tombstones on well-tended grassy knolls. ``It was wrong,'' said Norman Moore, former president of the Marion-Washington County chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. ``It was degrading to see.'' The plaintiffs _ the local NAACP and some individuals _ say they hope the order, which comes seven years after a lawsuit was filed over the practice, will finally put a disturbing remnant of segregation to rest. Elizabeth Mendel, Ryder Cemetery Co.'s lawyer, said her client will decide whether to appeal after U.S. District Judge Charles Allen specifies what work needs to be done. The judge's order, issued earlier this month, simply directs the cemetery to remove the wire fence and ``provide equal care to all sections.'' Three years ago, the cost of getting the black side up to the white side's maintenance level was estimated at $50,000. The 30-acre cemetery, incorporated on land donated in 1865 by a German immigrant, appears to have been segregated from the start. Although no records exist to explain the arrangement, the cemetery company never maintained the ``colored section'' or took money for plots in it, but left maintenance to blacks, who sometimes collected fees. For more than 10 years, blacks willing to buy the $200 plots have been buried with whites on the cemetery's well-tended side. But most blacks say they want to be laid to rest near relatives in the black burial ground. ``In the summer the weeds are up over my head,'' said Lily Mae Bell, whose husband is buried on the black side and whose son is on the white side. Bell, 71, said she likes to visit both graves but finds it a chore to pick her way around the fence, which is topped with barbed wire, and make her way through the field. ``You really get muddy,'' said Bell, who was a plaintiff in the suit. Thelma Riley, 63, another plaintiff, said: ``The fence is what burned me up. You go and see it and wonder why. I told somebody, `Nobody's ever going to come up out of the grave and walk over to the other side.'''

DOC.HEAD: Unorthodox College Produces Oscar Nominee Crop of Nine
DOC.TEXT: Hampshire College has produced nine Oscar nominees in its 19-year history, an achievement that alumni say showcases the starring role of their design-your-own-degree curriculum. ``The whole thing just boils down to a very simple thing ... It is the proof that Hampshire College not only works, which 20 years ago was a big question mark, but it works fantastically,'' said graduate Ken Burns. Burns has been nominated twice for an Academy Award in the documentary category, for ``Brooklyn Bridge,'' and ``The Statue of Liberty.'' Robert Epstein, one of two Hampshire graduates to win Oscars, was nominated this year in the best full-length documentary feature category as a co-director of ``Common Threads: Stories from the Quilt.'' The documentary is about the AIDS quilt being pieced together in front of the White House. Epstein took home an Academy Award in 1985 for his documentary on Harvey Milk, the San Francisco homosexual politician who was murdered. In all graduates have been nominated nine times for Academy Awards. In 1986 graduate Thomas Sigel won in the best documentary short category for his film, ``Witness to War: Doctor Charley Clemens.'' Hampshire opened in 1970 as an alternative to the traditional education offered at nearby Smith, Amherst and Mount Holyoke colleges and the University of Massachusetts. Students at the college design their own courses of study and advance through three divisional examinations requiring them to complete individual research projects. That freedom may explain why students have been able to catch the eye of the academy, film professor Jerome Leibling said. ``The fact that they think they can design it and do it themselves ... film lends itself to that. It's disciplined, but it's also spontaneous. We allow that to happen. They're not being being graded or pushed and they can absorb a great deal,'' he said. Burns, who is finishing a nine-part history of the Civil War to be broadcast on public television, said Hampshire students weren't spoon-fed and ``that has really put us in a good position to capitalize on our particular area of expertise when we got out into the real world.'' Film graduates have to complete a film and Leibling said some of the most successful alumni produced work that helped them step up to the professional level. ``I think that's very important,'' he said. ``We have an idea that it is doable and that they can do it and we have the equipment and the time.'' He said he wasn't sure why students have been so successful in the field of documentary and short films, although he noted others have gone on to more commercial success in Hollywood.

DOC.HEAD: Chief Minister of Troubled Province Steps Down
DOC.TEXT: The top official in Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto's home province has stepped down after weeks of bloody political clashes that prompted charges the government could not maintain order. The chief minister of Sind Province, Syed Qaim Ali Shah, handed in his resignation to Ms. Bhutto late Saturday. On Sunday night, the provincial assembly elected a distant relative of the prime minister, Aftab Shabaan Mirani, to replace Shah. At least 70 people have died in recent ethnic strife in the southern port city of Karachi, Sind's capital and Pakistan's largest city with 8 million people. Many officials in the governing national Pakistan People's Party had criticized Shah's leadership, accusing his government of being unable to control the volatile situation. Most of the clashes have been between supporters of Ms. Bhutto's Pakistan People's Party and the Mohajir Qaumi Movement, made up of Moslem immigrants who fled to Pakistan from India when Pakistan was created in 1947. The violence peaked on Feb. 7 and 8. Clashes between police and sharpshooters belonging to rival political groups left scores dead and hundreds wounded. On Sunday, the English-language Nation newspaper reported that a politician from the Mohajir movement was killed the day before while he was sitting in his shop. There were no details.

DOC.HEAD: Hundreds Rally to Back Mayor Wounded by Rightist
DOC.TEXT: More than 700 protesters marched Sunday to denounce the shooting of Nagasaki's mayor by a rightist angered by the official's comment that the late Emperor Hirohito bore some responsibility for World War II. ``Let's discuss the emperor system more freely!'' protesters shouted as they marched a mile through Nagasaki, on Japan's southernmost main island of Kyushu. They carried banners with slogans reading ``Freedom of speech with no taboo'' and ``Denounce terrorism.'' Mayor Hitoshi Motoshima, 68, was shot in the back on Jan. 18 at the entrance to Nagasaki's city hall. He was released from a hospital Wednesday. Police arrested Kazumi Tajiri, 40, of Tokyo, a member of a rightist group, five hours after the shooting. They said Tajiri had admitted shooting the mayor. An official of the Nagasaki state police, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Sunday's demonstrations were orderly, and there were no disturbances by rightists. Before he was shot, Motoshima was subjected to more than a year of threats for his December 1988 remark that Hirohito ``shares responsibility for the war, as well as all of us who lived in that period.'' His remarks outraged rightists, many of whom revere the imperial family. Hirohito, who died in January 1989, was worshipped as a living god before renouncing his divine status after World War II. Motoshima and some others maintain Hirohito could have ended the war sooner, sparing Nagasaki from the atomic attack on Aug. 9, 1945, three days after a nuclear strike on Hiroshima.

DOC.HEAD: Six Killed in Bus-Car Crash in Indianapolis
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 2 grafs for last graf, `She said ...' to UPDATE with bus destination, report that weather play no apparent role, backgroud. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Six people were killed and at least 13 injured Sunday when a Ford Mustang and a Greyhound bus collided on Interstate 65 on Indianapolis' southern outskirts, state police said. All of the dead were in the Mustang, said State Police Dispatcher Ronda Oliver. Thirteen bus passengers were injured in the crash, said Oliver, who added that about 25 people were on the bus. The most serious injury was a broken leg, she said. She said details of the crash were still sketchy, and authorities still had not identified all of the dead and injured. The bus was en route from Louisville, Ky., to Chicago. Reporters on the scene said the stretch of highway where the crash occurred appeared clear of ice and there was no indication recent bad weather played a role in the crash.The deaths brought to 14 the number of people killed on Indiana highways since Saturday.

DOC.HEAD: PRECEDE: Los Angeles
US To Report Marked Increase in Mexican Marijuana Production
DOC.NOTE: EDS: UPDATES throughout with State Department and DEA spokespersons confirmation of pending report and reaction to Times estimates
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration confirmed Sunday that it has determined marijuana production in Mexico is much higher than it previously estimated but downplayed reports of a tenfold increase. The Los Angeles Times on Sunday reported new U.S. figures, to be released this week, concluded Mexico produces 10 times more marijuana than previously beleived. The newspaper said the official U.S. estimate _ derived from CIA spy satellite photographs _ concluded that Mexico produced 47,500 metric tons of marijuana in 1989. In 1988, the U.S. estimated Mexico's production at 4,750 metric tons. Katherine Shaw, spokeswoman for the State Department's international narcotics section said the agency would release an annual report on foreign narcotic production and anti-drug efforts later this week. ``This is not a tenfold increase in one year,'' Shaw said of estimates on Mexican marijuana production. ``This is a revised estimate for 1989. There's a high probability things were much higher than we thought for a long time.'' Shaw said the estimates for the previous few years were relatively low and the new figure for 1989 is based on new methodology. The figure for 1988 she said was ``unsupportable.'' ``It's just been much higher than we've thought and this year we can prove it.'' U.S. officials have long suspected Mexico was underestimating its marijuana production figures. The U.S. figures are expected to be released Thursday, the Times said. Shaw would not confirm the 47,500 metric ton production figure reported by the Times. An administraation official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the number was ``in the ball park'' and noted that it reflected marijuana production after eradication efforts. Anti-drug officials told the newspaper the figures don't mean production in Mexico has exploded, but rather that previous estimates, based largely on information supplied by the Mexican government, were too low. Despite the new information, the Bush administration plans to certify that the Mexican government has cooperated in illegal drug suppression and is eligible for foreign aid, the paper said. But the disclosure is expected to inflame Congress. When asked whether Mexico would be certified as having cooperated sufficiently in anti-drug efforts to receive its full foreign aid Shaw said, ``the president hasn't signed any piece of paper yet.'' Mexico's deputy attorney general, Javier Coello Trejo, when told of the figures during a meeting with Drug Enforcement Administration chief John C. Lawn, ``nearly went into apoplexy,'' the Times said, quoting a source who spoke on condition of anonymity. But not everyone inside the Drug Enforcement Administration is convinced the new figures are correct, including John P. Sutton, who heads the agency's cannabis investigation section. He called the estimates ``inordinate'' and ``wild'' and said the U.S. analysts mistakenly included in their count ``ditch weed,'' wild-growing marijuana that lacks the kick of cannabis sold for smoking and has no commercial value. He also suggested other vegetation may have been included in the marijuana count. Frank Shults, DEA spokesman said, ``the development of production estimates is very soft and it always has been.'' ``We never say we know how much of any drug is growing anywhere,'' he added. But others, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the conclusions were solid. ``This is the first time we've done it right,'' one-high ranking source told the newspaper. The satellite pictures permitted estimates from areas where the Mexican government previously denied surveillance flights. By contrast, estimates for Colombian marijuana production went up to 2,810 metric tons for 1989, a slight increase from the 2,740 metric tons reported for 1988. In the United States, production for 1989 was estimated at 5,500 metric tons, with 4,600 metric tons for 1988. Other strains between the Bush administration and Mexico include a disclosure that the Mexican ruling party reportedly made a covert contribution of $11 million to the re-election campaign of Nicaraguan President Daniel Ortega. The Mexican government has also expressed anger over U.S. complaints of official foot-dragging and failure to cooperate in the investigation of the kidnapping and murder of DEA agent Enrique Camarena in 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Two Players Winner $52 Million Jackpot in Illinois Lottery
DOC.TEXT: Two Illinois lottery players accomplished what millions have failed to do in three previous weeks, matching all six Lotto numbers to capture a grand prize of about $52 million, the lottery director said Sunday. Despite cold weather and blowing snow that caused accidents and closed roads, ticket sales peaked Saturday afternoon, hours before the drawing for the second biggest Lotto prize in Illinois history, Illinois State Lottery Director Sharon Sharp said at a morning news conference. ``We ended up selling nearly $37 million worth of Lotto tickets in the past week,'' she said. The total revenue collected for payouts in Saturday's Lotto was more than $72 million, she said. The large grand prize and high sales volume followed three straight rollovers of the Lotto jackpot after no one matched all six numbers in the drawings of Feb. 3, Feb. 10 and Feb. 17. In its 16-year history, the Illinois lottery has never had a weekly jackpot roll over four times. The previous biggest Illinois jackpot was $69.9 million, divided by four Lotto players who each matched all six numbers in the drawing of April 15, 1989. The weekend's winning numbers were 25, 31, 35, 36, 39 and 47. As usual, the winners' identities cannot be confirmed until they step forward and have their tickets validated by lottery officials.

DOC.HEAD: Permit Applicants Threaten Suit, Remain in Line
DOC.TEXT: Driven by a rare chance for permission to build homes in this scenic ski and gambling resort, about 140 people spent a fourth day camped outside the library in snow and below-zero temperatures. The would-be builders _ some huddled in crudely built igloos and snow caves _ held their ground even though the county government on Friday withdrew a plan to issue the coveted permits on a first-come, first-served basis Monday morning. A smaller contingent waited outside City Hall, hoping for a crack at a separate batch of permits controlled by the city government. The impromptu camp-out demonstrates the voracious appetite for property in this town that boasts ski slopes, scenic vistas _ and a chance to gamble just across the state line in Nevada. Tough anti-development policies enacted in the early 1970s have kept construction at a virtual standstill around Lake Tahoe, in the Sierra Nevada within a day's drive of San Francisco. ``The people in front of us have waited 14 years to build on their lot,'' said Diane Rosner, one of about 60 outside City Hall. Concerned about the line and spurred by allegations of favoritism in the permit process, the El Dorado County Board of Supervisors voted Friday to cancel their plans to issue 123 permits by lottery. But the applicants, who began lining up Wednesday, vowed to stay, and to sue if the lottery didn't proceed. ``We do not intend to be dispersed,'' said Doug Rosner, a South Lake Tahoe real estate broker who was 34th in the line Sunday. Dale Sare, an attorney for about 100 permit applicants, said his clients would to remain in line until Monday morning and will sue unless the county issues the permits. With rare exceptions, building has been stopped in the Tahoe basin since the early 1970s in an effort to save Lake Tahoe from being clogged with algae caused by nutrients that wash off cleared land and into the lake. A settlement to numerous lawsuits was recently reached, and officials of the city and four counties which have territory in the moratorium area are working out how to issue permits. In an emergency session late Friday, county supervisors withdrew their plan, saying they would decide March 6 how to issue the permits. The city of South Lake Tahoe planned to make 62 permits available Friday on a first-come, first-served basis.

DOC.HEAD: Oily Water Seeps into Wetlands Area
DOC.TEXT: Water contaminated with crude oil from a tanker spill broke through a berm Sunday and flowed into a marsh, covering at least three birds in oil. ``There is a minor threat there,'' said Gary Gorman, director of the Huntington Beach Wetlands Conservancy, which is trying to restore the 25-acre marsh into a wetlands wildlife habitat. The oil got into a mud flat and pickle weed that is habitat for federally listed endangered birds. The birds soaked in oil were taken to cleaning stations, said Gorman. Workers from the Orange County Flood Control District rebuilt the berm while clean-up crews tried to contain the oil, Huntington Beach Fire Battalion Chief Dennis Groat said. A ruptured oil tanker spilled 400,000 gallons of crude off Huntington Beach Feb. 7, closing 12 miles of beaches in Orange County, south of Los Angeles. The last of the crude washed ashore last week. A combination of high tide and surf overwhelmed the earthen berm and water containing oil from the rocks spilled over the top, flowing toward the marsh.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands Attend Funeral of Former Salvadoran President
LaserPhoto SAL2
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of people chanting ``Duarte! Duarte!'' lined the streets Sunday for former president Jose Napoleon Duarte, who was buried with honors and eulogized as ``the father of Central American democracy.'' Vice President Dan Quayle, Costa Rican President Oscar Arias, Guatemalan President Vinicio Cerezo and former Honduran President Jose Azcona Hoyos attended a Roman Catholic funeral Mass for Duarte, who died Friday. He was 64. Arias and Cerezo were among the pallbearers for the founder of the Christian Democratic Party. Party leaders criticized the rightist government of President Alfredo Cristiani as ``niggardly'' for not declaring a national day of mourning. At least 100,000 people paid their last respects to the departed former president, party leaders said. Duarte's followers, many carrying photographs of the former president and cheering, ``Duarte! Duarte!'' tossed flowers at his flag-draped coffin as it was carried from the church to a 21-gun military salute. Arias, speaking at the Mass, called Duarte ``the father of Central American democracy.'' ``Napoleon was a visionary pioneer and an untiring fighter for democracy,'' Arias said. Cerezo referred to criticisms of Duarte's 1984-1989 term as president but said, ``I think the magnitude and value of his work still has not been fully appreciated.'' He ``gave his life for the cause of all democrats of Latin America,'' Cerezo said. Duarte, who tried but failed to end a civil war and ease El Salvador's searing class division, died at his San Salvador home after struggling against stomach and liver cancer for almost two years. Fidel Chavez Mena, who succeeds Duarte as the Christian Democratic leader, criticized the government for not declaring a day of mourning but added: ``the people were in mourning, anyway, which is the important thing.'' Cristiani was unable to attend the funeral because he is on a state visit to Taiwan. Cristiani, who represented the oligarchy that Duarte has fought for decades took over as president in June 1989 after his conservative Nationalist Republic Alliance, or Arena, defeated the Christian Democrats. Armando Calderon Sol, mayor of San Salvador and Arena president, said: ``Duarte was an expression of democratic will. He made great contributions toward the democratization of the country.'' ``We have been strong adversaries,'' Calderon said. But, he added, ``It would be unjust not to recognize President Duarte's palpable efforts for human rights (and) struggle for freedom of expression.'' Duarte's body was transported to a private cemetary in southern San Salvador for burial. After founding the Christian Democratic Party, Duarte was tortured and exiled for seven years. He returned in 1980 and headed a civilian junta until he was chosen president in 1984 in the country's first elections in 50 years.

DOC.HEAD: Snowy Sunday Means Canceled Religious Classes, Slick Roads
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with snowfall in New England; chain-reaction accidents in New York and Massachusetts, Connecticut; conditions as far south as North Carolina; other details; minor editing; trimming. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Arctic air Sunday brought an abrupt end to weeks of unseasonably mild weather in the Northeast, and roads slippery with snow created numerous chain-reaction pileups and forced cancellation of church services. ``We didn't get January in January, so we're getting it in late February,'' said Mel Goldstein, director of the Weather Center at Western Connecticut State University in Danbury. Two days after highs reached the mid-60s in New York City, Philadelphia and Boston, Sunday's afternoon readings were only in the low to mid-20s, with wind gusting to 30 mph in New York. The National Weather Service said Boston would chill to zero overnight with wind making it feel like 35 below. By Sunday evening, 4 inches of snow had fallen in Boston, the weather service said. Across Massachusetts, snowfalls ranged from 4 to 10 inches. The snow caused a 30-car fender-bender on Interstate 91 near Holyoke, Mass., but state police reported only minor damage and no injuries. Blowing snow was being blamed for a massive chain-reaction pileup on Interstate 87 near Saratoga Springs, N.Y. Fifteen people suffered minor injuries. A person at the scene said a whiteout from the blowing snow blinded several drivers, who began sliding sideways and banging into each other. Real temperatures _ without the wind factored in _ were expected to drop as low as 25 below zero Monday morning in parts of the Adirondack Mountains in northern New York, said weather service forecaster Larry Bach in Albany. Nearly a foot of snow fell in parts of Connecticut, with accumulations ranging from 10{ inches in Litchfield and 10 in New Canaan to 5 inches in Vernon, Colchester and Norwich, the National Weather Service said. Roads were treacherous and several accidents were reported, including one involving a bus on Interstate 84 in Manchester in which 13 people received minor injuries, state police said. The storm that hit New England started Saturday around the Great Lakes and Ohio Valley. Chain-reaction crashes involving as many as 100 vehicles and other traffic accidents in bad weather killed 13 people in Ohio Saturday, nine of them in one pileup; three in Illinois; and one each in Michigan, Indiana and Kentucky. Among the churches that canceled services was First Baptist in Norwood, Mass., said Ron Nicholas, the church's pastor. ``Several of our people who came in on the hope of setting up had seen several accidents,'' he said. As far south as North Carolina, winds reached up to 50 mph, blowing trees and limbs onto utility lines and causing at least 3,500 people to lose power over the weekend, authorities said. Overnight temperatures Saturday ranged from 5 below zero at Mount Mitchell, N.C., to 19 degrees in Murphy. Power company crews were out in force over the weekend repairing downed lines. Ohio was especially hard hit by Saturday's storm. Nine counties were closed _ all roads shut down _ under snow emergencies and thousands of homes were without power during the storm, which ended early Sunday. Service had been restored to most electrical customers by Sunday. Seneca County's closing stranded fans overnight at the Ohio Conference women's basketball championships at Heidelberg College. ``Some of them spent the night in university rooms, some of them stayed in local hotels and we sent some to St. Francis Convent in Tiffin because we ran out of room,'' said Vicki Lucas, a college security officer. At least nine people were killed and 55 injured in an 18-vehicle crash on Interstate 75 outside Dayton, Ohio, Saturday while three pileups involving a total of 99 vehicles snarled traffic on I-75 near Findlay. ``In my 18 years, this is by far the worst I've ever seen,'' State Highway Patrol Lt. Dan Dickerson said of the pileup near Dayton. At least one gas tank burst into flames, and witnesses said thick smoke hampered rescue efforts. ``There was cars all over the place. We could hear people screaming. It was just terrible,'' said Alice Haynes, whose car was hit from behind. On Sunday, Ohio police and wrecker crews finished clearing the tangle of twisted and burned vehicles from the snow-covered stretch of I-75. In Michigan, only minor injuries were reported in three crashes on I-94 involving at least 130 vehicles in all, and in a 100-vehicle collision on I-75 north of Pontiac.

DOC.SECOND: Attorney General Launches Campaign for California Governor
DOC.TEXT: California Attorney General John Van de Kamp formally launched his campaign for governor Sunday in rival Dianne Feinstein's political backyard with a scathing attack on her record as mayor of San Francisco. Van de Kamp began with a rally at the Mission High School boys' gymnasium, in the heart of the city where Feinstein served nine years as mayor, and ripped into Feinstein's fiscal management and her record on civil rights, insurance, the environment and women's issues. ``Dianne Feinstein's budget mismanagement turned the city by the bay into the city that could not pay,'' Van de Kamp said, accusing her of being evasive on how she would balance the state budget. Van de Kamp describing himself as a candidate who ``is going to change California'' with environmental, political ethics and drug reforms. A spokesman for Feinstein called Van de Kamp's attack a sign of desperation in the wake of the most recent poll on the June 5 Democratic primary, in which the former mayor pulled ahead of the attorney general. The kickoff announcement is only a formality, since Van de Kamp, like Feinstein, has been actively campaigning for a year and leads Feinstein in fund raising by $4.6 million to $2.3 million. The winner of their June 5 primary will face the expected Republican nominee, U.S. Sen. Pete Wilson, in November. Incumbent Gov. George Deukmejian, a Republican, is retiring. Van de Kamp's campaign for governor is tied closely to three ballot initiatives he is sponsoring on the environment, legislative ethics and crime. The content of Van de Kamp's initiatives has also stirred controversy. Part of his crime initiative duplicates an initiative sponsored by Wilson, except for deletion of privacy language which Van de Kamp claims could undermine a woman's right to abortion, and his political ethics initiative contains a controversial limit on the terms of legislators. The ethics proposal has strained Van de Kamp's relations with legislative leaders of his own party, not only because of the proposed limit on their terms, but especially because of a supporting article Van de Kamp wrote in which he said of the Legislature, ``if we want clean government, it's time to drain the swamp.'' Van de Kamp, 54, is a member of the wealthy Pasadena family which formerly owned the frozen food company and the Southern California bakery chain which still carry the family name. Before his election as attorney general in 1982, Van de Kamp served seven years as Los Angeles County district attorney, five years as federal public defender and two years as assistant federal public defender in Los Angeles.
