DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Sunday he and Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany agreed in weekend talks that a unified Germany would continue as ``a full member of NATO,'' including military participation in the Western alliance. Kohl said ``neutralism would be a very false solution.'' After two days of discussions regarding delicate issues of a unified Germany, Kohl said he recognizes ``the legitimate security interests of all states'' in Europe, particularly Poland. ``Nobody needs to be afraid,'' the West German leader said. Bush chimed in that if he were alarmed about the prospect of a single Germany, he would not be endorsing reunification _ as he had several times previously. There have been fears in Poland _ decimated by the Nazis in World War II _ that a new Germany would seek to regain border territory that was formerly under German rule.

Inside the former local Communist Party headquarters, 17 opposition groups work under the same roof but with different visions of how to rebuild East Germany after the nation's first free elections next month. Environmentalists, feminists, the well-known New Forum and even a lone conservative group all rent office space from the Communists in the neo-Gothic building, renamed Democracy House after the Communists moved out in January. ``It's a little chaotic here,'' campaign worker Jana Reuter of New Forum said Friday. ``It's taking a while to get the hang of things.'' Others praise the camaraderie and conveniences of similar groups working under one roof.

The nation's governors put their stamp Sunday on national education goals, but got no encouragement from the White House for the prospect of financial help from a ``peace dividend.'' The executive committee of the National Governors' Association expanded the six goals proclaimed by President Bush in his State of the Union address last month by spelling out a series of specific objectives. The governors also endorsed a resolution calling on the president ``to dedicate the peace dividend in a balanced manner between the federal budget deficit, education and other productivity investments.'' Democratic Gov. Roy Romer of Colorado failed in an attempt to get the governors to adopt a resolution that urged the president to ``direct substantial federal resources from defense to educational needs and other productivity investments.''

Former President Reagan repeatedly endorsed false letters to Congress in his videotaped testimony for John Poindexter's Iran-Contra trial. The letters, written by former national security adviser Robert McFarlane and which form the basis of one of the criminal charges against Poindexter, categorically deny that Oliver North was raising money or giving military advice to the Nicaraguan rebels. Reagan said he does not know to this day that the letters were false. He also said he did not know that McFarlane, Poindexter's predecessor in the Reagan White House, pleaded guilty to crimes in connection with the letters or that the Tower Board that Reagan appointed three years ago concluded that North had been assisting the Contras militarily. Poindexter, facing trial March 5 on charges of conspiracy, obstructing Congress and making false statements, sent responses to Congress in 1986 that embraced McFarlane's letters of the previous year.

Louis Sullivan, after a shaky start as the nation's top health official, has seized the anti-smoking campaign as his own, winning kudos from Congress and grabbing headlines with talk of ``blood money'' and ``trading death for corporate profits.'' Following the well-worn path of previous federal health officials, Sullivan, the secretary of Health and Human Services, has cranked up the war of words against tobacco companies to new heights. ``He certainly has found an area where he has been willing to be outspoken and has taken the leadership,'' said Rep. Henry Waxman, D-Calif., chairman of the House Energy and Commerce health subcommittee. But some say smoking is a safe issue, since Sullivan isn't attacking tobacco subsidies or proposing a ban on advertising. And they say Sullivan, who for nearly a year has run the federal department with the largest budget, has yet to show such bold leadership on the larger issues confronting the administration, including the nation's soaring health-care bill.

Eight-year-old Erik Hundley of South Nyack, N.Y., rattles off the civil rights struggles of Martin Luther King Jr. after a week of study but admits, ``I forgot who Harriet Tubman was.'' Sameena Parveen, 13, an eighth grader at Kettering Middle School in Largo, Md., is intrigued with the underground railroad movement and the role of a virtual unknown, John Henry. And, 12-year-old LaKeisha Lewis of Spencer, Okla., becomes ``sort of angry'' when she thinks about ``how the civil rights thing came about ... because I don't think people should be treated like that.'' The study of black American heroes and heroines went into high gear in schools this month, as it does every February, in recognition of Black History Month. Although started in 1926 by Carter G. Woodson in recognition of the birthdays of Abraham Lincoln and Frederick Douglass, celebration of the special month gained momentum when King's birthday became a national holiday.

A Democratic candidate for governor who borrowed the Republicans' Willie Horton strategy was forced to apologize after the tactic was denounced as racist and prejudicial to a defendant. Gubernatorial hopeful Rep. Bill Nelson kicked off his campaign Feb. 14 by promising to make a Florida case involving a black defendant into his rival's ``Willie Horton _ only worse.'' On Friday, he issued his apology. The six-term congressman is considered the front-runner among the three Democrats seeking a chance to challenge first-term Republican Gov. Bob Martinez. Martinez also has three Republican challengers. Horton, who had spent 10 years in prison in Massachusetts for murder, escaped during a furlough in 1987 and raped a Maryland woman and assaulted her fiance. A commercial during President Bush's 1988 campaign blamed Democrat Michael Dukakis for the tragedy and was credited as a major factor in the Massachusetts governor's defeat.

Under the scrutiny of thousands of international observers, Nicaraguans voted Sunday on whether to continue the leftist Sandinistas' 10-year rule or hand power to a U.S.-backed coalition. Voters lined up before dawn at some of the 4,394 polling stations and waited patiently for hours to choose between the incumbent president, Daniel Ortega, and his only serious challenger, Violeta Barrios de Chamorro of the United National Opposition, or UNO. ``It's very solemn, like a Mass,'' said former President Jimmy Carter, watching poll officials lay out ballots, registration books, ink, and scissors on a table in one of the stations. Carter and more than 3,000 other observers were spread out across the nation to guarantee the election's fairness.

From Siberia to the southern republic of Georgia, hundreds of thousands of Soviets rallied for democracy in more than 30 cities Sunday, despite official warnings that the Soviet Union's first nationwide protest could explode in violence. More than 100,000 people turned out in Moscow, and smaller protests occurred elsewhere. The official warnings, which were repeated frequently last week in the state-run media, kept the turnout low in some cities and prevented some protests altogether. Riot police dragged away people who tried to hold an unsanctioned demonstration in Leningrad, but there were no reports of major unrest. In Moscow, the crowd grew through the afternoon as initial tension gave way to a relaxed and good-natured atmosphere. One column of marchers was led by a man with a bullhorn who told police and bystanders, ``We represent no danger.''

The leader of the Sajudis reform movement said Sunday that independence for Lithuania could be achieved this year after his group claimed a landslide victory in the Soviet Union's first multiparty election. In balloting for the Baltic republic's 141-seat parliament Saturday, voters appeared to have chosen the country's first legislature not dominated by Communists. The main contenders were the Sajudis Popular Front, which has led the drive for independence, and the reformed Lithuanian Communist Party. On the street outside the Sajudis headquarters, passers-by gathered excitedly around posters announcing the victory.

Malcolm Forbes, the multimillionaire magazine owner, motorcyclist, balloonist and self-proclaimed ``capitalist tool'' who reveled in life and free enterprise, has died of a heart attack at age 70. Forbes died in his sleep Saturday afternoon at his 40-acre estate in Far Hills, N.J. ``Death happens to everyone but we never believed it would happen to him; he always defied the odds,'' said Forbes' son, Malcolm Jr., who will succeed his father as editor in chief of Forbes magazine and chief executive officer of Forbes Inc. magazine. ``What he wanted inscribed on his tombstone says it all: `While alive, he lived,''' the son said at a Sunday news conference with his sister and three brothers.

DOC.HEAD: Drexel Bankruptcy Keeps Millions From Lawyers
DOC.TEXT: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. owes millions of dollars to lawyers who helped defend the collapsed Wall Street firm and its employees during the government's lengthy insider trading investigation. Atop the list is Drexel's main outside counsel, which has claims to $2.1 million in back fees, and attorneys for indicted junk bond ex-king Michael Milken, whose monthly allowance of about $1 million wound down when Drexel went belly up. ``There are outstanding fees they haven't paid and they're not going to pay anything going forward,'' said a Milken associate who asked not to be named. When Drexel became entangled in the largest Wall Street criminal probe ever, the firm promised to pick up the tab for all current or former employees who became involved. In addition, the demise of the firm that dominated Wall Street junk-bond dealmaking is affecting big law firms that derived a large amount of work from Drexel's criminal woes and its day-to-day securities business. A slowdown on Wall Street _ investment banking firms need lawyers for activities from underwriting stocks to completing mergers _ hasn't helped either. ``There are more than a few lawyers who will be poorer for all this,'' said Columbia University law professor Harvey Goldschmid. ``Because of the deals and the prominence, Drexel has been a terribly important player for a meaningful part of the legal community in New York.'' Roger Meltzer, a partner with Cahill Gordon & Reindel, which has represented Drexel for 10 years, conceded that Drexel's demise would hurt, but added that the firm has a ``substantial and diverse client base.'' The firm reportedly did about $10 million in Drexel business a year. Cahill Gordon said in court papers it is owed $2.1 million. ``This firm is not based on the financial health of one client,'' Meltzer asserted. ``Never has been. Never will be.'' Drexel said it spent $75 million on legal fees associated with its criminal and civil troubles last year, when it pleaded guilty to six felonies and paid $500 million of $650 million owed in government penalties. A mountain of litigation spawned by Drexel's behavior still is outstanding. The government's investigation made Drexel a legal cottage industry, and its collapse leaves bills scattered from coast to coast. Lawyers for current and former employees said they expect to press for some of the millions owed; at least one major New York firm has its bankruptcy lawyer examining the issue. ``Everybody would like to be paid,'' said Gerald Lefcourt, who represents Bruce Newberg, a former Drexel junk bond trader who has been convicted of securities fraud and was indicted along with Milken. ``I don't know whether we will or won't.'' With Drexel busy disposing of billions of dollars in securities holdings and addressing the thorny matter of having paid $260 million in bonuses as its financial fortunes sank, paying more money to lawyers hasn't been a priority. ``They're pretty busy. I haven't been able to get through,'' said Daniel Bookin, a San Francisco attorney for Lisa Jones, a former Drexel bond trading assistant who is appealing her conviction for lying to a federal grand jury. Drexel spokesman Steven Anreder said backed-up legal bills ``will be dealt with in due course'' but he didn't know how much was owed. Anreder said Drexel had for the time stopped paying for individuals' new legal expenses. Drexel reportedly owes Milken attorneys _ mostly at the New York firm Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison _ back pay for three or four months, consistent with what other firms representing Drexel people claim is due. The firm capped spending by Milken's criminal defense team last summer, after it had rung up gargantuan legal bills to pay for two full-time lawyers who reportedly bill out at $450 an hour and a football team worth of associates. Drexel also anted up for Milken's defense against civil lawsuits claiming his actions as head of Drexel's high-yield bond division defrauded investors. The arrangement was unusual to begin with: Drexel paying to defend the man who allegedly masterminded the crimes to which the firm admitted. A spokesman for Milken said the indicted financier would foot his own expenses from now on. For Milken, who made $550 million in 1987, that won't be a problem. Other clients, such as Lisa Jones, depended on Drexel to pay the bills. But Bookin, her attorney, said his firm ``will not abandon Lisa Jones.'' No attorneys have as yet filed claims against the firm or its parent, Drexel Burnham Lambert Group Inc., which filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection on Feb. 13, seeking to get the back pay. The dismantling of Drexel also has created legal complications for civil claimants who say they were defrauded by Drexel trading in the past, and that means more work for lawyers. Drexel's liquidation doesn't absolve the firm from civil wrongdoing, and lawyers said they will seek to recover assets from the firm if their claims are upheld. They also said they will try to find out whether Drexel wrongfully drained away assets, including the 1989 bonuses. ``They still have all their legal liabilities and are not protected by a bankruptcy case,'' said Dan Mogan, a San Diego attorney representing shareholders of companies with which Drexel had dealings.

DOC.HEAD: Unions, LTV Reach Tentative Agreement
DOC.TEXT: Negotiators for the United Steelworkers of America and LTV Steel have reached a tentative labor agreement that could avert a strike, officials said. Union spokesman Gary Hubbard said the agreement, approved early Sunday by union negotiators, also must be approved by the union's International Executive Board, by almost 13,000 steelworkers employed by LTV and by a U.S. Bankruptcy Court judge. Parent LTV Corp. filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in July 1986, listing $6 billion in assets, making it one of the country's biggest industrial bankruptcies. Terms of the agreement, which was agreed to take effect Sunday, were not released. In a statement, the union said it expected the executive board to act quickly on the pact but did not say when the board would meet. ``The new labor agreement is competitive with recent settlements between the Steelworkers and other domestic steelmakers,'' said David H. Hoag, LTV Steel's president and chief executive officer. ``However, it has several unique features, including the establishment of a joint customer satisfaction initiative that will involve the entire LTV Steel work force in our effort to continuously improve our quality and customer service.'' Steelworkers employed at 13 LTV locations will vote by mail via secret ballot, the union said. The vote will not take place until the agreement is considered by Burton Lifland, the bankruptcy judge who is supervising LTV's reorganization. LTV produces engineered flat rolled and tubular steel products and is a wholly owned subsidiary of LTV Corp., a manufacturing company also involved in aerospace, defense and energy products.
